Existing Wording: When populating the organization and location hierarchies there is often not a clear distinction between these 2, however to assist in making the decision, Locations are always used for recording where a service occurs, and hence where encounters and observations are associated. The Organization property on these resources may not be the location where the service took place.
Comments: There is some ambiguity regarding when to use a Location vs. an Organization (encounter or observation could reasonably use either one).  Recommend that there is more explicit language to determine when to use one vs. the other so that clients know what to expect.
Summary: Clarify use case for Location vs. Organization.

Existing Wording: This specification does not specify merge functionality: if multiple patient records are found to be duplicates, they can be linked together, as described above.
Comments: This language leaves multiple alternatives for server behavior when receiving a merged-off resource ID for a patient.  Suggest defining required behavior to redirect to current patient with a notification of content location change.
Summary: Require server behavior for merged patients.

Existing Wording: An address in any kind of address/part of the patient
Proposed Wording: Remove
Comments: Address is a valid search parameter, but it is not granular enough; it is difficult for a server to search on a string that could be any part of an address.  Address should be its own type made up of line address, city, state, etc. See existing GForge tracker item 3918
Summary: Make the address search parameter its own type with subdivisions rather than simply a string.

Existing Wording: Schedule.actor has resource type of "Any"
Proposed Wording: Update to match to participant.actor
Comments: The type of actor should be limited to resources which can realistically be scheduled, not any resource. This should be consistent with the types of actors supported by Appointment.
Summary: Schedule.actor has resource type of "Any"

Existing Wording: participant.actor is currently 0..1
Proposed Wording: Believe that this should be 1..1
Comments: the use of participant needs further definition and clarification. Please define the required elements for each participant in the list - a participant without an actor is meaningless
Summary: participant.actor should be required

Existing Wording: This specification is complete enough to be implementable in a variety of healthcare scenarios, including supporting all content from the Consolidated CDA implementation guide.
Proposed Wording: This specification is complete enough to be implementable in a variety of healthcare scenarios, including supporting all "Common MU Data Set" amd and much other content from the Consolidated CDA implementation guide.
Comments: I don't believe that ALL of CCDA has been put into FHIR, but the focus has been mainly on the MU2 data (Common MU Data Set plus related items), as prioritized by Argonaut and DAF. While FHIR contains more than the Common MU Data Set, there are less frequently used sections and entries of CCDA, especially those note needed for MU2 -- that have not yet been covered.
Summary: Not ALL of CCDA has been incorporated yet.

Comments: careProvider "Good Health Clinic" is omitted from the human readable narrative although it is included in the Standard Data for Patient. This does not set a good example, to leave out a piece of data that is not a "processing use only" attribute (like an OID or codesystem). I suspect this was carried over from CDA where display of "Header" is not consistently specified, and where Provider might be omitted if it was included in a Stylesheet.
Summary: Should include Provider in the human-readable narrative portion.

Existing Wording: is intended to be useable world-wide in a wide variety of contexts - in-patient, long-term care, community care, allied health, etc.
Proposed Wording: is intended to be useable world-wide in a wide variety of contexts - in-patient, ambulatory care, long-term care, community care, allied health, etc.
Comments: "Ambulatory care" was conspicuously missing
Summary: Add ambulatory care to list of contexts

Existing Wording: 1.7.2.2 Building useful Clinical Systems out of Molecules…
Comments: I suggest eliminating this as a section. Move the first paragraph to be the last paragraph of 1.7.2.1 and eliminate the second paragraph, which is more confusing than helpful. The "molecule" analogy in the title is not followed through. The description of a prescription referencing other resources that "are maintained in their own folders and cabinets" introduces a new analogy that sounds nonintuitive and complex to a clinician (who would not thinks of a prescription as a complex set of links, even though technically it is).
Summary: Merge first paragraph of 1.7.2.2 into 1.7.2.1. and eliminate second paragraph

Proposed Wording: Try to be constructive
Comments: The concept of "folders" (see my comment on 1.7.2.2) would not resonate with clinicians in the way it's described. They'd think of a patient chart as a big folder, but they wouldn't think of each resource (like a medication or an allergy) as a "folder."

Existing Wording: This resource is extends resource.
Proposed Wording: This resource extends the Base Resource.
Comments: Typo extraneous "is." Also suggest capitalizing and making the link more explicit (to Base Resource).

Existing Wording: All resources have the following optional or mandatory elements and properties: an identity, meta data, a base language, a reference to "implicit rules"
Proposed Wording: All resources may contain the following elements and properties: an identity, meta data, a base language, a reference to "implicit rules" If contained in a resource, the elements may be mandatory or optional.
Comments:
This is confusing as worded and doesn't seem consistent with the resource definitions that I see. For example, if "all" resources have these elements, why don't I see them all in every resource? E.g., the Patient resource spec (5.1.x) doesn't list id, meta, base language, or implicit rules, although id is shown in some of the Examples. 
When 1.10.2. says "optional or mandatory" I'm not sure whether by "optional" it means that "the element is present with cardinality 0..1 or 0..*," or whether it means that "the element may be absent." IF it means the element may be absent, then the alternative wording may be clearer.

Existing Wording:
Once assigned, the identity is never changed, though copies of the same resource made elsewhere may not retain the same identity.
…
Copying or moving resources from one server to another means that resources acquire a new identity. For further details, see Managing Resource Identity.
Proposed Wording:
Once assigned, the identity is never changed, though copies of the same resource made elsewhere may not retain the same local identity.
…
Copying or moving resources from one server to another means that resources acquire a new full identity, which may or may not include a new local identity. For further details, see Managing Resource Identity.
Comments: "may not" sounds like it means "might or might not" i.e., is ambiguous, but then the next paragraph says that "resources acquire a new identity" on a new server. The confusion in this section arises from referring initially to the relative identity within a server and resource (e.g., patient id="123"), which I'll call the "local" identity. Then the second paragraph still says "identity" but means the "full identity" i.e., the URL. So moving to a different server will definitely change the full identity, but might not change the "local" identity. If my understanding is correct, the proposed wording tries to explain the distinction between local identity and full identity. In any case, I suggest the wording of this section be clearer.

Existing Wording: However all copies of the reosurce
Proposed Wording: However all copies of the resource

Existing Wording: For example, the guidance listed for CDA would apply to Consolidated CDA (CCDA), Continuity of Care Document (CCD) and other CDA profiles.
Proposed Wording: For example, the guidance listed for CDA would apply to Consolidated CDA (CCDA) and other CDA implementation guides.
Comments: CCD shouldn't be listed separately because it's part of Consolidated CDA. Also, should use the term "implementation guides" since CDA doesn't really have "profiles."

Existing Wording: Note that none of these tools are able to check complete conformance to this specification.
Comments: What is the answer then? Shouldn't there be testing tools that can check complete conformance to the FHIR spec, as well as to specific FHIR Profiles?
Triage Note: note that complete conformance testing will always require human inspection

Existing Wording:
An element is labeled "Is-Modifier = true" if the value it contains may change the interpretation of the element that contains it …
When an element is labeled as Is-Modifier, the documentation must be clear about why it is a modifier.
Comments: I expected the example in 1.11.2 to say somewhere "Is-Modifier-true" but don't see that labeling anywhere in the example. The description and example don't clarify how "didNotOccurFlag" is an instance of "Is-Modifier=true"

Existing Wording: cancelled – the planned activity will not take place
Proposed Wording: cancelled – the planned activity did not start and will not take place
Comments: Clarify some confusion that cropped up when people looked at "aborted" vs "cancelled" in mapping efforts

Existing Wording: A characteristic set of states for the clinical workflow process pattern include:
Proposed Wording:
A characteristic (but non-exhaustive) set of states for the clinical workflow process pattern include:

SAY MORE
Comments: The examples of the clinical workflow pattern use several states that are not in the "characteristic set of states" above. It would certainly be helpful if consistency were established whenever possible, to avoid situations where the same words are used with different meanings or even contradictory meanings. I'd like "cancelled" to always mean "cancelled before it started." Otherwise, I could foresee someone defining "aborted" to have the same meaning as "cancelled" or these two words could even flip flop meanings across different workflows, which would be very confusing (suppose someone used "aborted" before something started and "cancelled" after it started).

Because there is no enforced consistency, it doesn't seem to me that these are "patterns" at all, just a list of activities that have some vague similarities. So I suggest that each heading end with the word "Lifecycles" rather than "Pattern," e.g., "Entity Availability Lifecycles"

I suggest removing the table entirely until more items have definitions. Even the ones that are not "Unknown" are not clear. For example, what does ".status=retired" mean for Conformance and why is it not ".status=entered-in-error" like Composition?
Triage Note: That's the purpose of the table - because the codes / approaches are different. Committees need to work on this

Existing Wording: External references - references from resources found elsewhere
Proposed Wording: External references - references to resources found elsewhere
Comments: Surely "to" was meant. At least all the descriptive text talks about references to things, and the text says "References are always defined and represented in one particular direction - from one resource (source) to another (target)."

Existing Wording: However FHIR provides no mechanism for defining or constraining any conduction of "equivalent" properties from a containing resource into any contained resource - not even by declaring the use of a particular profile. Best practice is to explicitly include all known properties on contained resources, even if redundant with properties on the containing resource.
Comments: Why not avoid this problem by requiring contained resources to explicitly state their subject? Why allow this degree of optionality?
Triage Note: well, our experience is that we can't get everyone to agree with making this required.

Existing Wording: servers will need to make arrangements to make some resources with no direct link to a patient available to the client (medications, substances, etc.).
Proposed Wording: servers will need to make arrangements to make some resources with no direct link to a patient available to the client (medications, substances, etc.). For example, a Medication resource describes the medication itself and does not link to a patient; however, a resource such as MedicationAdministration connects the Medication (what was administered) to the patient (for whom was it administered?).
Comments: Using "Medications" as an example of a resource not directly linked to a patient at first seems nonintuitive, because the term "Patient Medication List" is so common. Then I realized that the statement literally implies an understanding that a "Medication" resource defines the med itself, independent of patients, but the medication can be indirectly linked to the patient through another resource such as MedicationAdministration or MedicationPrescription. But since "Medication List" is such a common concept, I suggested the additional words to clarify.

Existing Wording: The narrative for a resource is allowed to contain additional information that is not in the structured data, including human-edited content.
Proposed Wording: The narrative for a resource is allowed to contain additional information that is not in the structured data, including human-edited content. The converse is not true: structured data should not contain information of importance to human readers that is omitted from the narrative. Creators of FHIR resources should not assume that systems will render, or that humans will see, data that is not in the narrative.
Comments: The best practice of representing ALL human-relevant information in the narrative is important to avoid people missing it. No assumptions can be made about querying/receiving systems rendering. Recent problems surfaced regarding CDA instances where structured entries contained more information (e.g., additional lab results) than was in the narrative.

Existing Wording: If narrative is present, it SHALL reflect all content needed for a human to understand the essential clinical and business information otherwise encoded within the resource.
Comments: Strongly agree. This is important to say, so that important information is not "buried" in structure that is not shown to humans. Thanks for the SHALL.
Summary: Ignore

Existing Wording: Narrative for a resource should include summary information about referenced resources as necessary for a consumer of the resource to be able to understand the key essential information about a resource without retrieving additional resources. For example, the narrative for a MedicationPrescription might include brief summary information about the referenced patient, prescriber and medication.
Comments: I understand why this is stated, so that when a single resource (e.g., MedicationPrescription) is accessed, a human can understand that Dr. Smith wrote this Rx for John Doe. However, if there is a request for multiple resources, or a list of resources, or a FHIR document, then how is this "summary information about referenced resources" to be rendered without being verbose and redundant? For instance, a medication list for John Doe shouldn't have to list John Doe with each item in the list. A document composition would typically have the patient displayed at the top, but not shown again for every section or (worse) for every resource. Is there a way for the system to "suppress" unnecessary reference narrative for lists, documents, and multiple resource retrievals?
Triage Note: great question. For discussion / testing at connectathon

Existing Wording: human written narrative may be the only content if the list has no entries (which would equate to a narrative only section in a document).
Proposed Wording: human written narrative may be the only content if the list has no entries (which would equate to a narrative only section in a document). However, the content should still be regarded by humans as a list, e.g., a manually entered list of past procedures without structured entries. But narrative that is not a "list" at all, such as a Chief Complaint,  should not use the List resource.
Comments: It is legitimate to have narrative-only section, but it does not make sense to call it a "List." A list should be a set of things of the same or similar character, e.g., a med list, a problem list, a result list that might in narrative be represented as bullets, enumerated, or a table. Narrative that is "paragraphs" or not a set of entries -- e.g., Hospital Course, Chief Complaint -- does not fit the definition of a list. The suggested wording tries to clarify.

Existing Wording: Lists will typically include references to the resources that make up the list, however in some cases the details of the content of the List might be expressed in narrative only. E.g. A text record of a family history.
Comments: See my comment on 6.1.5 -- it does not make sense to call these types of narrative a "List."

Is Instant necessary as a datatype? I'm not sure why the Instant datatype is not just a "simple restriction" (constraint) on DateTime like the other restrictions in 1.18.0.1.2? I don't understand why use by "systems" rather than "humans" requires a different data type. After all, couldn't the system also use a code, an id, or other data types, yet we don't have extra data types for each of them.
Triage Note: Well, it is a constraint on date time., and does need to be defined, but we could make the constrait-ness more explicit

Existing Wording: In the second case, the contained extension is defined separately.
Proposed Wording: In the second case, the registrar field of the contained extension is defined separately.
Comments: It seems to me that the first two fields of the extension (status and date) are not defined separately, but are defined identically to the first example. Only the last field (registrar) seems to be defined separately. If my interpretation is correct, the proposed wording clarifies what is "separately defined."

Existing Wording: Applications may also be able to ignore a modifier extension if that can know that this is safe to do in its own context, though this would not usually be the case.
Proposed Wording: Applications may also be able to ignore a modifier extension if they know that this is safe to do in its own context, though this would not usually be the case.

Existing Wording: <MedicationPescription>…</Procedure>
Proposed Wording: <MedicationPrescription>…</MedicationPrescription>
Comments: MedicationPrescription "anti-prescription" example has a typo in its first tag, and has </Procedure> as the ending tag.

Existing Wording: 1. HL7 approved extensions, approved by an appropriate part of the HL7 community following a review process, and with have formal standing
Proposed Wording: 1. HL7 approved extensions, approved by an appropriate part of the HL7 community following a review process, and which have formal standing

Comments: Thanks for adding a link to the ToC at the bottom of each page, in response to my comment on #95 the previous ballot. But I suggest calling it "Table of Contents" which is easier to understand "Specification Map" -- the page that is linked to is called "Full Table of Contents" after all.
Triage Note: it was called table of contents

Existing Wording: A set of healthcare-related information that is assembled together into a single logical document that provides a single coherent statement of meaning, establishes its own context and that has clinical attestation with regard to who is making the statement.
Proposed Wording: A composition defines the structure for a set of healthcare-related information that is assembled together into a single logical document that provides a single coherent statement of meaning, establishes its own context and that has clinical attestation with regard to who is making the statement. While a Composition defines the structure, it does not actually contain the content: rather the full content of a document is contained in a Bundle, of which the Composition is the first resource contained.
Comments: The distinction between the document as assembled, vs the composition as a structure and "pointer" to the resources, is fuzzy in this opening paragraph, which makes it sound like the composition is itself the Document, whereas elsewhere the text clarifies that the document is actually a Bundle that includes Composition as one resource, plus other resources. The proposed wording tries to clarify more precisely that the composition defines the structure. I think of the Composition as being like a document's Table of Contents with hyperlinks, but not the document itself: is that a fair analogy?

Existing Wording: Kinds of mitigating actions and observations that can be associated with a contraindicaiton,
Proposed Wording: Kinds of mitigating actions and observations that can be associated with a contraindication,

Existing Wording:
Little River Home Maintenance
Example mowing services
Comments: I appreciate that many examples have been added. But these last two don't make sense -- home maintenance and mowing (is that lawn mowing?) How are these healthcare services?

Existing Wording: The HealthcareService resource is used to describe a single healthcare service that is being provided by an organization at a location
Proposed Wording: The HealthcareService resource is used to describe a single healthcare service or category of services that are provided by an organization at a location
Comments: "a single" is too limiting and does not fit the examples.

Existing Wording: There are five mechanisms in FHIR for communicating collections of resources:
Proposed Wording: There are four mechanisms in FHIR for communicating collections of resources:
Comments: Group, List, Bundle, and Composition are the only four mechanisms mentioned in 5.17.2. Either change the wording to "four" or add a bullet to explain the 5th mechanism (which might possibly be "contained resources" though I'm not sure if that's a "collection of resources").

Existing Wording: A Procedure Request is a record of a request for a procedure to be performed. It can be used to represent a procedure that is planned, that is proposed, or that is ordered.
Proposed Wording: A Procedure Request is a record of a request for a procedure to be performed. It can be used to represent a procedure that is planned, that is proposed, or that is ordered, as distinguished by the value of the ProcedureRequestStatus field.
Comments: I think it's important to be explicit about how to know the difference between proposals and actual orders, so I suggested the additional wording.

Existing Wording: Best practice is to explicitly include all known properties on contained resources, even if redundant with properties on the containing resource. E.g. If the containing resource and contained resource both have a "subject" element, both elements should be present, even if they reference the same resouce. Applications that choose to omit redundant elements on contained resources should not expect other applications to infer (or correctly infer) the intended meaning in this case. Applications cannot safely presume that omitted elements in contained resources can safely be inferred to be the same as the containing resource.
Comments: I commented on this in the last ballot. I still don't understand why this can't be made less "iffy." A contained resource cannot have an independent existence outside of the resource that contains it, according to 1.13.0.1: so why can't the subject, if blank, be always safely inferred to be the subject of the containing resource? What other subject could it possibly be, if this instance is its only existence? Yes its subject can be overridden, but I would rather that absence of subject always have the same predictable meaning of "same subject as container." Leaving it as a "best practice" that cannot be guaranteed leads to ambiguity which I think is unnecessary. I understand why an external reference cannot make the same assumption about a blank subject, but think it is safer and simpler to say that a contained resource has the same subject as its container, except when overridden.
Summary: From previous ballot, enter something about 162, 176, 177, 183, 187

Existing Wording: Using the Condition resource to record an assertion that a patient doesn't have a particular diagnosis (as opposed to refuted)
Proposed Wording: Using the Condition resource to record an assertion that a patient doesn't have a [particular diagnosis (as opposed to refuted). [Explain the subtle difference between "doesn't have" and "refuted"…]
Comments: This is an example where I thought that the resource-specific elements would make it unnecessary to define a modifier extension for a common clinical case. But when I look in 1.23.2.1.1848.1 at the definition, "refuted -- This condition has been ruled out by diagnostic and clinical evidence." That sounds essentially the same as "We assert that the patient doesn't have this condition." The difference is too subtle. I wouldn't want someone defining the modifier extension if they could have used "refuted" from the core.

It would help to have a link to the Document page /documents.html from the Resource list, even though (technically) a document is a type of bundle. Looking at the index, it seems strange to not see it there under the Documents & Structure category.

Existing Wording: However the content (the set of attested resources, and their order) and the presentation of the document cannot change.
Proposed Wording: However the content (the set of attested resources, and their order) and the presentation of the document cannot change substantially (such that it changes the clinical meaning of the content).
Comments: Early parts of the page refer to the document having "fixed" presentation and 2.3.0.1 says "the presentation of the document cannot change." However, 2.3.0.1.1 allows for different stylesheets besides those specified in the document. Even though it says the specified stylesheets SHOULD be used, that is not a SHALL. So if someone uses a different stylesheet, the presentation of the document might change, which contradicts the earlier statements. The proposed wording was borrowed from 2.3.0.1.1. However, more specific guidance is needed on what types of changes are permissible or not via stylesheets. E.g., "cosmetic" changes such as branding a document with your logo, or increasing the font size, seem innocuous and should be permissible. However, suppressing any of the narrative should be prohibited. What about rendering additional data that is in the structured elements but not in the narrative (is this OK)? Etc.

Existing Wording:
A request to perform an action
...
(in 5.24.1)
Note that orders are often called "requests", but this name is not used here since the word "request" is used differently elsewhere in this specification.
Proposed Wording:
A directive to perform an action
...
(in 5.24.1)
[eliminate this sentence]
Comments:
The definition of Order in 5.24, "a request to perform an action," is contradicted by the wording in 5.24.1. Proposed wording tries to clarify. 
The disposition of my comment on the previous ballot said 
"2015-01-19 - We recognize the challenge and suggest that PtCare, OO, FHIR, and CDS on Thursday review a suggestion to harmonize as much as possible the names of DiagnosticOrder, ProcedureRequest, DeviceUseRequest, NutritionOrder, MedicationPrescription, VisionPrescription, etc.
2015 - 01-22 OO/PC/CDS MOTION: Change referral request to referral order (PC), procedure request to procedure order (OO), device use request to device use order (ask devices) and communication request to communication order (CDS)."
These changes have not been made. However,  I realize that this section is flagged as "Draft"

Existing Wording: A supply - a request for something, and provision of what is supplied.
Comments: I commented on this in the last ballot (comment #176 and #177), and both were deferred, with lots of agreement in the disposition comment that it is confusing to blend both the request and the response in a single Supply resource, which is inconsistent with how other resources (Order, Device, Communication, Procedure, Appointment) are handled. I raise it again to keep in "on the current radar."

Existing Wording: A client can determine that an order has not been performed by searching for order resources with no matching responses (see below)
Proposed Wording: A client can determine that an order has not been performed by using the Order id to perform a search for Order Response resources that contain a Reference to this Order: if none are found, then there is no record that the order was performed (it is possible that the order was actually performed but that the act has not yet been entered into the system).
Comments:
First, "see below" does not appear to have text below that explains it. 
Second and more significant: "searching order resources with no matching responses" does not appear possible based on the Order search parameters. I see no field in Order to indicate the existence of responses. My proposed text may help, though I'm not sure if that is the correct way to do the query, and it seems like it wouldn't work if the Order id is unvalued (which it can be, given cardinality of 0..1).  
Also I added the parenthetical remark because I think it's wise to be cautious about inferring negation (non-performance) if that has not been asserted. 
This was my comment #183 in the last ballot, which was deferred with the following disposition comment:
2015-01-22 18:27:47.439921+00 :
Based on discussion with FHIR and Devices in the room, we need to review with Grahame the three paths of establishing whether an order has been performed or not: presence of a link between OrderResponse and Order; the OrderResponse.code; or status on the specialized order resource, e.g., DiagnosticOrder.status.
Additionally, OrderResponse.code is not a good name for its content, and whether the status reflects the status of the response, or the status of the order it responds to. Perhaps OrderResponse.proposedOrderStatus might fit better, but we do not know given current descriptions.
2015-02-14 07:12:20.013933+00 :

Existing Wording: The list is prepared as a statement of changes that have been made or recommended.
Proposed Wording: A list that indicates where changes have been made or recommended.
Comments: Previous ballot, comment #187, the disposition comment said "Change definition for "changes" List.mode: A list that indicates where changes have been made or recommended."  However, that change was not made, so the definition is still not quite right.

Existing Wording: The final mode - a changes list, may include deleted items. A typical case is a medication list in a discharge summary, where the list includes items that have been both added and deleted. In order to ensure that the list is safe to process, any item where the flag implies that the item has actually been deleted SHALL have the deleted element set to true.
Proposed Wording: The changes list indicates where there are changes, but may also include deleted items as well as items that have not changed. A typical case is a medication list in a discharge summary, where the list includes items that have been added (new), deleted (stopped), and continued (unchanged). In order to ensure that a "changes" list is safe to process, any item where the flag implies that the item has actually been deleted SHALL have the deleted element set to true.
Comments: Remove "the final mode" which sounds like it’s another mode ("final") in itself. Also clarified the medications list to be more accurate to what must be on a med list (not just changes). Finally, reworded "the list" to "a changes list" so that it does not refer specifically to the medication list example.

Existing Wording: Each resource may include a human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource, and may be used to represent the content of the resource to a human.
Proposed Wording: Each resource may include a human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource, and may be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative is included in the "Domain Resource" type within a specific individual Resource definition.
Comments: I am surprised I didn't ask this previously. It is not obvious where to find the narrative in a resource. Though it's in the "Domain Resource" but that is not intuitive. I suggest that this be clarified in this section describing Narrative: see Proposed Wording.

Existing Wording: All of these changed definitions SHALL be restrictions that are consistent with the rules defined in the base resource in the FHIR Specification.
Proposed Wording: All of these changed definitions SHALL be restrictions that are consistent with the rules defined in the constrained resource in the FHIR Specification.
Comments: Saying "base" resource could be confusing since there is a specifical "Base Resource" section (1.10) in the FHIR spec.

Existing Wording: Logical id of this artefact
Proposed Wording: Logical id of this artifact

Existing Wording: SLOT   Resource Slot
Comments: Remove (or deprecate) this from the Basic Resource Types value set because Slot is already a FHIR resource in the Scheduling/Ordering category.

Existing Wording: This value set defines its own terms in the system http://hl7.org/fhir/basic-resource-type
Comments: The URL does not work. Get an HTTP 404 error. Also, the sentence is confusing: how can the "value set" define its own terms? People define terms. The process for defining new terms should be explained more clearly in 6.3.6.
Triage Note: The URL will work once DSTU2 is published. Guess we have to extend 6.3.6

Existing Wording: Many documentsections will correspond
Proposed Wording: Many document sections will correspond

Existing Wording: If it is necessary to make use of the Basic resource, try to use one of the HL7-defined codes for resource type or submit your requirement for a new type for inclusion in the HL7 vocabulary, as this will increase the likelihood of interoperability.
Comments: It does not say where to submit the request for a new code. FHIR Management Group? Vocabulary WG? Where? I suggest that be included in the text.

Existing Wording: The base definition for elements defined as part of a resource.
Comments: What is an "element" vs a "backbone element?" In 1.20.0, the definition of Element ("The base definition for all elements contained inside a resource") sounds almost the same as the definition for Backbone Element ("The base definition for elements defined as part of a resource"). What is the distinction between elements "contained inside a resource" vs "elements defined as part of a resource?"

Existing Wording: 11.23.2.1  /C-CDASmokingStatusValue.html
Comments: The URL does not work, produces an HTTP 404 error.

Existing Wording: Human readability approach: CDA and FHIR both require that content be human-readable and define specific rules for how the human readable text is presented. One small difference is that in CDA, the human readable portion is defined for the section, while for FHIR the text is on the resource the section points to.
Proposed Wording: Human readability approach: CDA and FHIR both require that content be human-readable and define specific rules for how the human readable text is presented. One difference is that in CDA, the human readable portion is defined for the section, while for FHIR the text can be both on the resource as well as the List resource that references the resources.
Comments: The paragraph as written is not entirely true, since FHIR documents will probably use List resources which can have their own narrative which may not be exactly the sum of the narratives of the individual resources in the list (as described in FHIR 6.1.5).  I think this is more than a "small" difference so I deleted the word "small." Also, the paragraph implies that FHIR has a "section" that points to resources, but there is no FHIR "section" resource. Proposed wording tries to clarify.

Existing Wording: The other difference is that, for FHIR, the human-readable aspect is not limited to the document - it's driven by the resource itself. This may result in slightly less flexibility in rendering approach if a document is compiling existing resources.
Comments: Is the red text true? Since the List resource can have its own narrative, which is not necessarily equal to the sum of its collection of resource narratives, it seems to have the same flexibility as a CDA section, which can be derived from its entries (analogous to resources) or have the narrative be independently authored by a human or machine.

Existing Wording:
the recording of an intake medication list upon admission to hospital

the summarization of a patient's "active medications" in a patient profile
Proposed Wording:
the recording of each medication in an intake medication list upon admission to hospital

the representation of a medication as part of a summarization of a patient's "active medications" in a patient profile
Comments:
These examples are incorrect and confusing because they imply that the medication statement is used for a "list" or "summarization." However, the definition of medication statement is singular, i.e., for "a record of a medication." 
The proposed wording clarifies that the medication statement is for each individual medication that is part of a list, but that the medication statement is not a list of multiple medications.

Add "List" to the related resources. See also my comment on 4.16.1. Medication Statement, Prescription, Dispense, and Administration all refer to a single medication, but these are generally conveyed in CDA documents as part of a list.

Existing Wording: CarePlanActivityCategory (required)
Comments: I believe that it is premature to make the value set defined in section 1.23.2.1.39.1 required. It should be just an example at this point. The Care Plan DAM is still in progress and its Activity Classification should be used when ready. The specific values seem too narrow and I don't know whether the codes shown (e.g., "diet", "drug") will be the ones chosen. I don't think "encounter" should also encompass "communication" or that "procedure" should encompass "education" since those may be categories of their own.

Existing Wording: healtchare-related
Proposed Wording: healthcare-related

Existing Wording: Unrecognized search criteria SHALL always be ignored. (Search criteria supported in a query are echoed as part of the search response so there is no risk in ignoring unexpected search criteria.)
Comments: I suggest striking or softening the statement about "no risk." This statement may not always be true, since it depends on what the impact of the unrecognized criteria would be. It might be obvious but it might be subtle. For example, if there is a query on the Patient Resource that intended to include patient ID and several other search criteria, but patient ID was erroneously submitted, might that search return unintended patients who matched the other search parameters?

Existing Wording: Value sets with an enumerated list of codes and having a 'fixed' binding may have additional codes introduced but will never have codes removed.
Proposed Wording: Value sets with an enumerated list of codes and having a 'fixed' binding may have additional codes introduced but will never have codes removed, but they may be deprecated.
Comments: Suggest providing a clarification to explicitly allow deprecation (sometimes it just makes sense).

Existing Wording: Documents: This question doesn't apply, because documents are bundles that are exchanged using one either REST, messages, or services
Proposed Wording: Documents: This question doesn't apply, because documents are bundles that are exchanged using either REST, messages, or services

Existing Wording: 4.3 Condition-daf-Condition-concernStatus
Proposed Wording: 4.3 Resource Condition - Content
Comments: The ToC links to the wrong page. 4.3 should link to the main Condition resource documentation (which also has section number 4.3), but instead it links to a page related to DAF which also has the same section number 4.3 (but should have a different #).
Triage Note: sigh. Thought I hunted all them down. Fix the build tool

Existing Wording: Procedures do not include actions things for which there are specific resources, such asimmunizations, drug administrations and communications.
Proposed Wording: Procedures do not include actions or things for which there are specific resources, such as immunizations, drug administrations and communications.
Comments: Typo. But also the phrase "for which there are specific resources" is vague: most procedures will require not only a Procedure resource but other associated resources (e.g., supply, observation, imaging study, device, specimen...). Need to reword the sentence to better explain the exceptions to using Procedure resource.

Existing Wording: This resource is limited to clinical issues associated with a proposed or ongoing action. It does not cover business/technical issues such as lack of permission, duplicate identifiers and other business rule violations. Business and technical issues are conveyed using theOperationOutcome resource.
Comments: When I looked at the OperationOutcome resource, I didn't see how it could represent anything other than "system actions/errors" but not business issues. One significant reason that an action might not occur is lack of financial resources (e.g., lack of insurance coverage). It would help if something were said about this either in Contraindication or OperationOurcome, or if the reader were referred to other resources that could be used (Eligibility?

Existing Wording: 4.20 Observation-genetics-cg-prf-1a-Observation-chromosome-genomicstart
Proposed Wording: 4.20 Resource Observation - Content
Comments: The ToC links to the wrong page. 4.20 should link to the main Observation resource documentation (which also has section number 4.20), but instead it links to a page about chromosome search parameter, which should have a different number
Triage Note: sigh. Thought I hunted all them down. Fix the build tool

Existing Wording: Representation of the content produced in a DICOM imaging study.
Proposed Wording: Representation of the content produced in an imaging study.
Comments: Suggest removing DICOM as an inherent part of the definition, but leaving the text in 4.23.1 to explain how DICOM is the main intent, but that this resource can be used for non-DICOM.

Existing Wording: 4.28 Familymemberhistory-daf-FamilyMemberHistory-relationship
Proposed Wording: 4.28 Resource Familymemberhistory - Content
Triage Note: sigh. Thought I hunted all them down. Fix the build tool

Existing Wording: If the device is implanted in a patient, then the patient element will be present, and there would be no location.
Comments: This is contradicted by the Device.location definition in 5.10.6, which says "The resource may be found in a literal location (i.e. GPS coordinates), a logical place (i.e. "in/with the patient"), or a coded location." Either change 5.10.1 or device.location definition.

Existing Wording: A record of a device being used by a patient where the record is the result of a report from the patient or another clinician.
Proposed Wording: A record of a device being used by a patient where the record is the result of a report from the patient, or another person.
Comments: Report may come from persons (e.g., caregivers, family members) other than patient and clinician

Existing Wording: 5.15 Location-extensions-Location-alias
Proposed Wording: 5.15 Resource Location - Content

Existing Wording: An absolute URI that identifies the Code System (if the source is a value value set that crosses more than one code system).
Proposed Wording: An absolute URI that identifies the Code System (if the source is a value set that crosses more than one code system).

Existing Wording: The OperationDefinition serves two principle purposes:
Proposed Wording: The OperationDefinition serves two principal purposes:

Existing Wording: Operation Definitions are published to define operations that servers can implemnet
Proposed Wording: Operation Definitions are published to define operations that servers can implement

Existing Wording: This resource is called "ClinicalImpression" rather than "ClinicalAssessment" to avoid confusion with the recording of assessment tools such as Apgar score.
Comments: I prefer to name the resource Clinical Assessment. I disagree with the reason for calling the resource "Clinical Impression." "Assessment" has been used widely in medical practice for a long time (e.g., the "A" in SOAP notes), and is still commonly used today. Just because there is a specific assessment tool such as Apgar doesn't mean that it hijacked the word "assessment" so that can't be used elsewhere! After all, there are specialized types of questionnaires, observations, procedures, interventions, etc., but none of them preempt the existence of generalized resources named Questionnaire, Observation, etc. FHIR should use commonly used healthcare terms, even though some terms may be used for multiple purposes, and clarify distinctions within its discussion.

I suggest that a Vision Prescription is a Clinical resource, just like other prescriptions or orders. I would make the same statement about hearing aids, prosthetics, dental care -- treatment of conditions for certain body parts shouldn't be considered non-clinical.

Existing Wording:
A document manifest gathers a set of Document Reference resources into a single package that may be the subject of workflow such as access control, auditing, and targeted delivery. 

Typically, Document Manifest Resources are used in document indexing systems, such as IHE XDS (see the XDS specific profile).
Proposed Wording:
A document manifest gathers a set of Document resources into a single package that may be the subject of workflow such as access control, auditing and targeted delivery. 

Typically, Document Manifest Resources are used in document indexing systems, such as IHE XDS (see the XDS specific profile). It will also be used to describe the content in an EHR extract.
Comments:
In the upcoming creation of a HL7  FHIR ISO EN 13606 extract Profile, there is a need of a resource with almost the same content as Document Manifest. The diffrence that not will be able to manage in the profile, is that we need to directly reference the content in the extract: :List(folder) and Composition resource.   
The alternative to this is to create a new EHR extract  resource.
Summary: Reference any resource in Document manifest

Existing Wording: The list of DocumentReference or Media Resources, or Attachment that consist of the parts of this document manifest. Usually, these would be document references, but direct references to Media or Attachments are also allowed.
Proposed Wording: The list of DocumentReference or Media Resources, or Attachment that consist of the parts of this document manifest. Usually, these would be document references, but direct references to composition, List, Media or attachments are also allowed.
Comments: Add reference either to any resources or reference to Composion and List(folder).
Summary: Reference any resources in Document manifest

Comments: Add possibility to use SNOMED CT codes for typecodes.
Summary: Using of Snomed CT

Comments:

Proposed Wording: Add to the content  description of an resource, a categorization under the Contsys concept
Comments:
ISO/FDIS 13940 (Contsys) is expected to be published within 6 months. 
Contsys is a complete and comprehensive system of concepts for healthcare and includes a clinical process model for clinical context. This International standard has been developed during a long period of time and comments from all over the world has contributed to the content, which makes it robust and sustainable.
Contsys aims to become the common basis for global development of semantic resources for interoperability. 
The current work with FHIR resources is not based on this system of concepts. The global efforts for harmonization would much benefit from using Contsys as the basis also for the FHIR resources. 
In comparison the concepts in Contsys is mostly more generic than the FHIR resources. To start with the current FHIR resources could be categorized under the Contsys concepts with possibilities to further alignment later.  Last summer we made a comparision between some Contsys concepts with relevant FHIR resources. We are glad to send the document to you. Email Karl-Henrik Lundell karlhenrik.lundell@gmail.com or Helen Broberg
helen.broberg@skane.se
Summary: Harmonisztion Contsys ISO 13940
Triage Note: Happy to add such a categorization

Comments: Need possibility to have relationship also to procedures and conditions, not just other observations.  As in e.g. Procedure.RelatedItem or Condition. OccorredFollowing
Summary: Observation.relatedItem

Comments:
Contsys has an informative but for the system of concepts important model of the clinical process. This gives possibilities for interoperability when it comes to clinical context. E.g distinction between investigations and treatment, basic or alternative treatments and so on are possible to define by the use of standardized context based on this model. Encounter is just one kind of "context" that could be needed to state in a resource (see observation.encounter).  Other example that could be needed is clinical process concern, demand for care, main health issue health problem or episode of care.
Create a new element to add, in all resources, and replace "encounter" with this in resources there "encounter" is used as a context reference. The element should be of different types: Identifier|Reference(Encounter|EpisodeOfCare|ClinicalProcessConcern). For some of the clinical contexts will require new resources, simulare to episode of care.
Summary: Context identifiers
Triage Note: discussion by MnM. Increase the level of abstraction, for what value?

A resouce always start with identifier and subject/patient e.g.as in Procedure and  Condition. But observation have this element as number 12th and 13th.
Summary: Order of elements
Triage Note: discussion By MnM. DO have a proposal on the table that W5 mapped elements always come first, and always in the w5 order

Comments: The ongoing revision of ISO 13606 will be harmonized with Contsys. The reference archetypes included in part 3 of that standard will much at the same level as the FHIR resources. The global harmonisation would much benefit from alignment of the ongoing development of FHIR resources and reference archetypes in 13606-3.
Summary:
Harmonization with ISO EN 13606
Harmonisztion Contsys ISO 13940

Comments:
This section needs to be re-done. With regard to the table:
1) Where is "binding type" defined? i.e., where is it declared in the "base specification" and what are the valid values? I think this is a vestige of previous versions of the spec. The bindings in the spec now seem to declare  "Binding Strength" as defined in 1.23.0.2 Binding Strengths, not these "binding types".
2) Where are these "profile properties" (conformance and extensible) defined? i.e., where are conformance and extensible values declared, and what are the valid values? Again, vestiges of previous versions? I would think if they're things you declare when creating a profile, that 2.14.0 Profiling FHIR would discuss them. But it doesn't. And the profiles that are part of the ballot have bindings that declare "binding strength" as defined in 1.23.0.2, not these properties. The discussions of "isExtensible" and "conformance" that used to be in DSTU1's 6.14.3.5 Binding Definitions and "incomplete" and "example" in 1.14.0.1 Controlling the use of Coded Values are gone now. If we aren't talking about conformance, extensible, incomplete, etc. any more and only about binding strength, this table needs to be deleted. If we still are talking about those things in addition to binding strength, they need to be defined and discussed.
Summary: Problems with the section "Mixing Custom and Standard Terminologies"

Comments: Two needs exist: 1) The need to express the laterality and relative position of a body site in a structured, post-coordinated fashion. In this case, there's no need to identify the site -- codes are sufficient to convey the location. For example, to express that a measurement was taken from the right index finger or that the left forearm was bruised, certainly the right index finder and left forearm are specific sites, but they needn't be assigned identifiers. 2) The need to identify a body site. For example, identifying a specimen or the specific sites of wounds (when the patient has multiple wounds) or of chest tubes (when the patient has multiple tubes). The body site resource seems to be attempting to solve both needs, whereas it might be better to separate the two needs and use different solutions for each. For need #1, a full resource requiring a patient id is undue complexity.  All that is needed is an inline complex element or data type that contains a CodeableConcept for the "main" location plus sub-elements of "laterality" and "relatedness" (proximal, upper, etc.). (There was a lot of discussion about the correct attributes, and in the end it appears it was just reduced to a single "modifier" element, but this is insufficiently exact in its semantics. At least a 0..* name/value pair is needed.) If further detail is needed (e.g., relation to some other body site), another complex type (either a separate type or a generalization of this one) could be constructed. Or maybe resources (like Observation) have just misused this resource. The text of Body Site says, "The BodySite resource is not intended to substitute for precoordination of codes. If precoordination of codes is supported by an implementation and a resource element has a choice of codeableConcept or BodySite, the codeableConcept should be used." But the problems are that a single CodeableConcept is insufficient for Observation's site and there is no complex structure to use instead.
Summary: Complext structure or data type needed for BodySite (not resource)

Proposed Wording: One of their purposes is to define variables, observations, or questions that include information about how to collect a variable's value--including information about data types and guidance about the use of answer lists and/or units of measure.
Comments: multiple typos
Summary: Typos in Data Elements vs. Codes

Existing Wording: Data elements (and their registries) and codes (and their code systems) serve different purposes. Data elements describe the characteristics of a piece of data while codes describe a particular concept (often in relation to other concepts). However, because data elements provide a definition of the meaning of a particular element, they can be thought of as being codes. One of their purpose is to define variables, observations, or questions, that include information about how to collect a variable's value--including information about data types, and guidance about the use of about answer lists and/or units of measure. This function is typically done by code systems such as LOINC and SNOMED CT. (Note that LOINC provides considerable detail about allowed answers, while most other code systems such as SNOMED only allow identifying the question.)It would be possible to treat a registry of data elements using a common identifier system/namespace as a code system. Similarly, data elements can be mapped to each other (and to codes) in the same manner as codes can be mapped by making use of the ConceptMap resource.
Comments: see tracker item 6266
Summary: Clarify the section

Comments:
Early designs of observation included a component element that had code + value. In an early ballot, this was removed because OO did not believe that there were genuninely observations where multiple values share the same metadata (perforner, reliability, method, reference range), but have component values. But increasingly, these are cropiing up. The most significant is blood pressure, which is an early thing for people to encounter. Another is the genetic observation profile - a whole heap of derived values. 

It's possible to treat these as related component observations, but this creates multiple observations, with multiple metadata (what's the implications of that?) and incurs processing overhead which has generated comment within the implementation community. I would like to bring back Observation.component, with the possible corollary that we limit it's use to some well described cases
Summary: Bring back Observation.component
