Existing Wording:
6.6.2 Audit Events are created as events occur, to track and audit the events. Audit Event resources are often (though not exclusively) created by the application responding to the create/read/query/update/delete/execute etc. event. A Provenance resource contains overlapping information, but is a record-keeping assertion that gathers information about the context in which the information in a resource was obtained. Provenance resources are prepared by the application that initiates the create/update etc. of the resource. 

6.5.1 Provenance resources are a record-keeping assertion that gathers information about the context in which the information in a resource was obtained. Provenance resources are prepared by the application that initiates the create/update etc. of the resource. An Audit Event resource contains overlapping information, but is created as events occur, to track and audit the events. Audit Event resources are often (though not exclusively) created by the application responding to the read/query/create/update etc. event. 
 
AuditEvent.object.lifecycle 
Definition 
Binding AuditEventObjectLifecycle: Required: http://hl7.org/fhir/object-lifecycle (Identifier for the data life-cycle stage for the object) 
Type code 
Requirements 
Institutional policies for privacy and security may optionally fall under different accountability rules based on data life cycle. This provides a differentiating value for those cases.
 Comments - This can be used to provide an audit trail for data, over time, as it passes through the system
 
Provenance Extension Most recent change - Definition
Provides the provenance record associated with the most recent update of the resource.
Comments:
[I may have totally misunderstood how the following FHIR capabilities are meant to work together, but this is the only sense I can make of the write up - so either I need more education on this and there needs to be better documentation or there's something fundamentally broken in the design, which wouldn't be that hard to fix.] AuditEvents are about actions performed on the server, which were initiated by an application, which may send Provenance about the context on the application side of a Resource that the application has uploaded, updated, executed, or deleted on the server.  The FHIR Provenance Resource at this juncture has no element to convey the Resource's life span on the application or the specific lifecycle event that triggered the application to upload, update, execute or delete it on the server.  According to the AuditEvent, all the details about what happened to the Resource are about actions on the server side, not on the application side, so that audit log isn't informative about what happened to the Resource on the application side.  Perhaps the application that prepares the Provenance Resource to send along with the target Resource could also send along a snippet of the target Resource's audit log in order to inform downstream users about the actions performed on the Resource on the application side.  But that means that the application has to be smart enough to determine what part of the audit log is relevant to the Provenance Resource being prepared to accompany the target Resource.  Taking this approach means that the sender has to send along two optional Resources along with the target Resource, and there's no guarantee that the receiving server is going to persist them together.  

Recommended fixes - Add an action element with binding to the ProvenanceEventCurrentState vocabulary [which is awaiting updating by the Security and EHR workgroup for appropriate workflow trigger events], add a pointer to the Provenance Resources to all entities involved in the generation of the target Resource, and add Lifecycle event to the Provenance Resource.  Remove any dependencies with the application or the server side AuditEvent Resources.
Summary: Rationalize the design of Provenance Resource and decouple from AuditEvent.

Existing Wording: 6.5.1.1 Extensions:  provenance - Most recent change: Provides the provenance record associated with the most recent update of the resource.
Comments: What's the use case for this extension - isn't the Provenance Resource itself supposed to be the provenance record associated with the most recent update of the resource?  Or was the intention to get the Provenance Resource of the predecessor Resource to this Provenance Resource's target???  Wouldn't it make more sense to have a pointer to the Provenance Resource associated with any entity that was used in the generation of the target Resource?  Then those entities' provenance records would point any entity used to generate them, so that the entire lifespan of a Resource and portions of a recource could be traced back of origination.
Summary: Replace the Provenance extension Most recent Change and add directly to the Provenance Resource as a pointer to the Provenance of each Entity involved in the current state of the target Resource.

Section: 1.23.2.1.513.1  Contract signer type: Signature Type Codes
Existing Wording:
The Digital Signature Purposes, an indication of the reason an entity signs a document. This is included in the signed information and can be used when determining accountability for various actions concerning the document. Examples include: author, transcriptionist/recorder, and witness.

Copyright Statement: These codes are excerpted from ASTM Standard, E1762-95(2013) - Standard Guide for Electronic Authenticaiton of Health Care Information, Copyright by ASTM International, 100 Barr Harbor Drive, West Conshohocken, PA 19428. Copies of this standard are available through the ASTM Web Site at www.astm.org. 

This value set defines its own terms in the system http://hl7.org/fhir/contractsignertypecodes
Comments: I negatively balloted this value set in January and it was supposed to be replaced with a signer type value set that incorporated the relevant ASTM signature types as signer types.   The ASTM codes denote the context in which a particular signature was executed.  That is orthogonal to the purpose of Signer Type element - which is to specify the role that the entity played when executing a signature on a contract or any of its profiles.  I have provided that value set to CBCC FHIR Facilitators, but time ran out before it could be loaded into the build.  Hopefully that can happen before the next ballot.
Summary: Replace the ASTM Signature Value Set with FHIR Signer Type value  [http://gforge.hl7.org/gf/download/docmanfileversion/8679/13096/valueset-contract-signer-type%203-30-15.xml]

Existing Wording:
Definition 
A set of Security-Tag codes specifying the level of privacy/security of the Document.
 
Control 0..* 
Binding HCS: Extensible: See http://hl7.org/fhir/vs/security-labels (Healthcare Privacy and Security Classification System) 
Type CodeableConcept 
Requirements 
Use of the Health Care Privacy/Security Classification (HCS) system of security-tag use is recommended.
 
 The confidentiality codes can carry multiple vocabulary items. HL7 has developed an understanding of security and privacy tags that might be desirable in a Document Sharing environment, called HL7 Healthcare Privacy and Security Classification System (HCS). The following specification is recommended but not mandated, as the vocabulary bindings are an administrative domain responsibility. The use of this method is up to the policy domain such as the XDS Affinity Domain or other Trust Domain where all parties including sender and recipients are trusted to appropriately tag and enforce. • [1…1] Confidentiality Security Classification Label Field • [0…] Sensitivity Security Category Label Field • [0…] Compartment Security Category Label Field • [0…] Integrity Security Category Label Field • [0…] Handling Caveat Security Category Field In the HL7 Healthcare Privacy and Security Classification System In the HL7 Healthcare Privacy and Security Classification (HCS) there are code systems specific to Confidentiality, Sensitivity, Integrity, and Handling Caveats. Some values would come from a local vocabulary as they are related to workflow roles and special projects.
Proposed Wording:
Requirements - Use of the Health Care Privacy/Security Classification System (HCS) Security Classification Label is required and must be the same code that is required to be used on the header of the CDA Document being referenced.  The Confidentiality codes that value the Security Classification Label are the complete hierarchical set of security classification levels ranging from the lowest non-classified level to the most classified level.  These levels indicate the clearance or level of the "need to know" that an authorized requester must have in order to access this information.  
Comments - Confidentiality codes convey security classifications used to permit or restrict access without revealing the specific sensitivities of the referenced document or other artifact.  No other Security Labels should be used in this context including the Sensitivity, Compartment, Integrity, Handling Caveat Categories or the Privacy Policy codes as these reveal the security clearance attributes that a requester must be able to claim or they indicate the sensitivity of information that only authorized user are permitted to access.  

Once access is granted to the reference document/artifact, an authorized user can access the other Security Labels used to convey governing privacy policies, information sensitivity, integrity of the information, and handling instructions such as permissible purposes of use, and any obligations or refrain policies with which the user must comply.
Requirements - Use of the Health Care Privacy/Security Classification System (HCS) Security Classification Label is required and must be the same code that is required to be used on the header of the CDA Document being referenced.  The Confidentiality codes that value the Security Classification Label are the complete hierarchical set of security classification levels ranging from the lowest non-classified level to the most classified level.  These levels indicate the clearance or level of the "need to know" that an authorized requester must have in order to access this information.  
Comments - Confidentiality codes convey security classifications used to permit or restrict access without revealing the specific sensitivities of the referenced document or other artifact.  No other Security Labels should be used in this context including the Sensitivity, Compartment, Integrity, Handling Caveat Categories or the Privacy Policy codes as these reveal the security clearance attributes that a requester must be able to claim or they indicate the sensitivity of information that only authorized user are permitted to access.  

Once access is granted to the reference document/artifact, an authorized user can access the other Security Labels used to convey governing privacy policies, information sensitivity, integrity of the information, and handling instructions such as permissible purposes of use, and any obligations or refrain policies with which the user must comply.
Comments: The DocumentReference.confidentiality element is munging the purpose of a confidentiality security label used in reference metadata with the use of security labels on referenced content for purposes of data segmentation, access control, receiver's policy compliance with permitted uses,  and user's obligations,prohibitions, and privacy marking handling instructions.
Summary: The use of the DocumentReference.confidentiality element is not conformant with the HCS requirements on Security Labels.  This needs to be fixed.

Proposed Wording: Yes
Comments: We probably need a standard extension on *Request to support capture of reasons for which the request was not performed. See communication.reasonNotPerformed in QUICK profile.

Proposed Wording: Add OrderResponse.reason, just like Order.Reason
Comments: Certain states, e.g., rejection are usually able to be associated with a reason for being in that state.
A section should be created describing the Order Request/Response pattern associated with FHIR, as this is a general pattern that could be associated with multiple kinds of orders.

Add David Hays excellent description of the Operations Framework to the top of operations.html.  See everything after Starting at Invoking an Operation in http://thefhirplace.com/2015/04/29/the-new-dstu2-operations-framework/

FHIR Profiles should always identify what they have changed with respect to cardinality, bindings, or data type restrictions.  It is otherwise difficult to understand them, especially in the context of a ballot.
Triage Note: They do. So I don't know what this is asking for

Comments: It is not clear where CORE extensions begin, DAF extensions begin and QICore extensions begin.  There should be an area where each body defining extensions is able to describe extensions.  This should be readily accessible from a profile publication
Add dependsOn element as an input Parameter with parts, and product as an output Parameter with parts.

Allow for multiple outcomes, with distinct codings.  Place message and equivalence underneath outcome.  Add suggested inputs above as parts to this new Outcome parameter.  This enables multiple codings to be returned from a translate request and the client to choose the appropriate one without another round-trip

Existing Wording: protocol  0..1 uri Clinical Protocol followed
Proposed Wording: protocol  1..1 uri Clinical Protocol followed
Comments: An impression can follow multiple protocols.
Completing a protocol is not that much different from implicitRules, why are these separated?

Please define some principles about how resource attribute content in FHIR is ORDERED and NAMED within a resource.  Compare ProcedureRequest and DiagnosticOrder and ReferralRequest, which according to FHIR section 4.7.2, could be used for the same thing depending on context. This required cross-domain decisions to be made, and some will not like it.  That was what I thought alternate names was supposed to help with across domains.
Summary: At this point, I don't have any clue why one resource says patient, and the other says subject, and one resource puts it at the beginning and another at the end.

Comments: The concepts in these three components need more harmonization.  I realize that these are all dealing with the general concepts at different levels, but many developers will not unless we either describe the relationships between them in more detail, or make them more obvious.
Is there an existing code system we can use as a recommended value set for risk probabilties?  NOT TO MY KNOWLEDGE and I do not recommend one.
Should risk assessments apply to devices, locations or any other resources (as part of the 80%)? Risk assessments are made to travel destinations.
Is identification of risk assessment method part of the 80%?  Not usually.

Is relative risk in the 80%? I have to pull teeth to get the absolute risk verbally from many providers.  Most start with "you have a three times greater risk of ____.", which is meaningless until you know what the original risk is.   However, both are used.  One should be clear which field is relative and which is absolute.

Existing Wording: Contract
Comments: The name is wrong, it should be something representing "Legal Document" but need not be contract.  For example, a Consent is NOT a contract in legal terms.
The exchange of electronic contracts does not seem to fit into the 80%.  I would recommend dropping this resource for something similar referencing legal documents.

Existing Wording: . subscriber ?! 0..1 Patient Plan holder information
Proposed Wording: . subscriber ?! 0..1 Person | Patient Plan holder information
Comments: The relationship between the subscriber and the Coverage is that of person, not patient.  My daughter just had care, but I am the subscriber, and she is the member with respect to coverage, and the provider's patient.  I have NEVER been a patient in her pediatrician's practice, nor at my wife's OB/GYN practice.   Patient would only be applicable at my physician's office under my coverage.

Proposed Wording: . member ?! 0..1 Person | Patient Plan member information
Comments: Add a member similarly defined as subscriber. The member describes the person whose coverage is being described.
The request contains no described services.  It should reference a DiagnosticOrder, ProcedureRequest, MedicationPrescription, ReferralRequest or similar request.
if these are not implicitRules, then I do not know what is.  I also know of few rules for which you would need to distinguish between original and current rules if both were specified.

This material does not seem to be aligned well with any activities or standards related to US claims.  While the FHIR resources might not be used to communicate to Payers, they could be used internal to a facility.  This misalignment could crticially challenge the adoption of FHIR Financial resources.

The Profiling for FHIR has inadequate governance procedure to effectively manage the US-realm profiles and extensions for federal, staff and organizational regulations and policy for key healthcare industry stakeholders. Text from the HL7 EHR-S FM R2, Conformance Chapter should guide the addition of improved governance of profiles.
Triage Note: Agree that US realm involvement is sorely lacking

Comments: The Extensibilty of FHIR has inadequate governance procedure to effectively manage the US-realm extensions for federal, staff and organizational regulations and policy for key healthcare industry stakeholders. Text from the HL7 EHR-S FM R2, Conformance Chapter should guide the addition of improved governance of extensions.
Triage Note: Agree that US realm involvement is sorely lacking

Comments: The epub document appears to be corrupt. Opens with iBooks on Mac OS X Yosemite and displays cover, but attempting to go to the next page results in a corruption message.
Summary: Epub is corrupted
Triage Note: Yes, it's corrupt. The core team would love to know why -as far as we can tell, it conforms to epub specification, and nothing gives us an informative error message

Comments: Currently, the FHIR base resource spreadsheet must declare all profiles. It would be preferable to have the profiled resource declare the external base resource that it extends. This small change would eliminate the need to edit the base resource spreadsheet in order to add a profile to the FHIR build. More importantly, having references point from profiles to base resources, rather than the reverse, would enable the core to be separated from the myriad profiles built on the core. It would lead to a more sustainable architecture, where the core was self-contained and inviolable. Correcting the direction of references is a necessary step to begin to modularize the build system, eventually to allow users to build their profiles locally, more quickly, and without recompiling the core.
Summary: Profiles should point to the base resource, rather than vice-versa.
Triage Note: Yes, we want to do this. But we didn't have any time or funding to address this when DAF Quick etc got thrown at us. And I'm still not sure what we do. Note, though, that I'm not really interested in a modular build system for things that are part of the core. Why would it be a feature that core editors can change resources without having to fix the profiles derived from them?  But build system stuff is out of scope for the ballot

Comments: The generation of resource, profile, extension, and valueset definitions (StructureDefinition and ValueSet XML and JSON files, the associated Bundle XML and JSON files, Schema/Schematron) should be completely independent of the generation of the HTML pages. Currently they are intertwined in Publisher.java. This makes local build times excessive, when an author may have no need to generate several thousand HTML pages, but still want to generate validated definitions.
Summary: Independent structure definition generation from documentation generation
Triage Note: It's an ongoing process to try and pick these things apart. It's also not obvious which particular things you do or don't want to generate when. Tracing dependencies in the tool is frightfully complex. Again, no time or funding support to do this either.  But build system stuff is out of scope for the ballot

Comments: If min or max of an ElementDefinition are not specified*, what is the cardinality of that element? The W3C says that the default cardinality of an element declared in XML schema is 1..1. Do the same rules apply for FHIR?  (*Note that ElementDefinition.min and ElementDefintion.max are optional, with cardinality 0..1)
Summary: Default cardinality of ElementDefintion min and max is undefined
Triage Note: check that we say that they have to be populated in a base structure, so that this question never arises

Comments: StructureDefinition snapshot views are not complete. If you want to compare a DAF profile with a QICore profile, you often need to fill in missing values -- for example, an attribute not included in the snapshot (of one or the other profile) that is included in the base resource or base data type. Some inherited attributes don't appear to get included in the snapshot unless part of the ElementDefinition changes -- for example MustSupports or cardinality.
Summary: Profile snapshot views are not complete.
Triage Note: Thought I had got all this nailed. Want to point out some examples?

Comments: Profiling, especially by the spreadsheet method, requires better “how-to” documentation. Everyone using FHIR needs to understand profiling. It a sense it is more important than the core. But the documentation is scant. The only way the QICore team managed was by trial and error and frequent 1-on-1 coaching from Lloyd. We have to get to the point where a novice can read the documentation, and successfully create a profile.
Summary: Need better "how-to" documentation for creating profiles
Triage Note: Well, I agree, but I think this is out of scope for the specification and therefore the ballot

Comments: The full TOC is very long. It would be convenient if the  user could expand and collapse sections, to open or close parts of the hierarchy.
Summary: Make sections of the full table of contents expandable/contractible

Comments: In addition to better "how-to" documentation on profiling, FHIR should provide guidance on best practices for profiling. There are many strategic and practical issues that are completely up in the air. For example: What standards should be followed in terms of profile naming? For URIs? When should a user specify an extension in the profile, versus at the resource level, or at the global level? Should profiles re-use structures such as extensions and bindings from other profiles sets? When should profiles profile other profiles? What should profiles in terms of constraining resource references? In what ways can different profiles relate to each other in terms of conformance, and what are the consequences?  Since every developer needs to create or consume profiles, this is extremely important.
Summary: Need best-practice documentation for creating profiles
Triage Note: Well, I agree, but I think this is out of scope for the specification and therefore the ballot

Comments: FHIR has great documentation of its core resources and its APIs, but there little or nothing how to use FHIR to achieve interoperability. What is the process that organizations should follow when they employ FHIR to solve an interoperability problem? What we need is a very clear, structured process, analogous to the NIEM process. Whether you believe in NIEM or not, it is an excellent example of how to explicitly lay out an entire interoperability solution process. We can’t assume people will pick up FHIR and know how to use it to solve real problems. There might be a temptation to leave this out of scope, but we do so at our own risk.
Summary: Need to create and document processes for achieving interoperability using FHIR
Triage Note: uh what? Are we going to dictate a process now? Is anyone going to agree to anything about this?

Comments: When you create a profile, what ultimately constitutes the normative description of the profile? Is it the documentation pages, or certain XML file(s)? For example, after the build there are 150 files with "qicore" in their names (and more have "qicore" in their innards). If someone asked me to send them the QICore profiles, just the profiles, what would I send them? Which ones constitute the actual specification of QICore, as opposed to informative or implementation-related material? How would you isolate this material from the rest of the FHIR?
Summary: The normative information on a profile needs to be separable from the rest of FHIR
Triage Note: I don't know. What isn't normative?

Comments: After a build, there are more than 15,000 files in the publish subdirectory. This may be an indication of incipient problems with the FHIR architecture in terms of modularity and sustainability. Currently, there are less than 100 resources. What will happen to FHIR when we start getting thousands of profiles? Can this architecture be sustained?
Summary: The build architecture is unsustainable
Triage Note: no the architecture can't be sustained. Needs discussion But build system stuff is out of scope for the ballot

Comments: As we built the QICore profiles, we periodically found cases where the documentation looked OK, but the profile XML had errors. The underlying problem is that the documentation and the profile XML are both derived independently from the spreadsheets, so there is nothing to prevent this type of hidden "forking" error. A more sound approach would be to create the profile XML first, and then derive the documentation from the profile XML. This would expose errors in lurking in the profile XML.
Summary: Documentation should be based on the profile XML.
Triage Note: ummm really? I don't think so anymore. The views are built from the profiles. Where's some examples of problems?

Comments: How would one create extensions and profiles that are not published by HL7? There is no documentation on how to do this, and I don’t believe it would be supported by the current build system, yet this is something that will be required to have FHIR scale to an international level.
Summary: How does a user create non-HL7 extensions and profiles?
Triage Note: Sure it's required. But we're su busy supporting the existing system that we have no time to figure out how to do that But build system stuff is out of scope for the ballot

Comments: Extensions should be able to live in their own namespaces. Every successful, scalable, distributed system that I’m aware of uses namespaces. When I say this, I mean proper namespaces, not pseudo-namespace by naming conventions. If that possible now, it isn't documented.
Summary: FHIR needs namespaces for extensions
Triage Note: Anything defined in the FHIR spec has to live in the FHIR namespace. Other people can define extensions in whatever namespace they want. Why are we having this discussion again?  But build system stuff is out of scope for the ballot

Comments: The build system needs a complete rethinking and a major overhaul. Currently, everything is one big monolith: it all has to work, or nothing works, and the bigger the monolith, the longer it takes. Incremental builds sometimes work, but often a complete build is required. As more groups build profiles, this will quickly reach a breaking point.
Summary: Build system needs to be redesigned
Triage Note: Sure. Needs to be done. But build system stuff is out of scope for the ballot

Comments: Currently, profiles cannot be built without other profiles also being built at the same time. It is possible to do a local build, but often updates in the core need to be brought in, which prompts a complete build. If I am working on my set of profiles, I don’t want to be delayed because someone else halfway around the world screws up their profiles (and vice-versa, I'm sure)
Summary: Build system needs to be redesigned

Comments: We need to re-examine whether using Excel spreadsheets is the best method for profiling. Our experience reveals the following: (1) It is slow and error-prone. (2) There is no way to compare across versions (diff doesn’t work). (3) You can’t easily search or find and replace across multiple files. (4) Cutting and pasting screws up formatting and data validation. (5) Each file has to be individually opened, edited, and closed. It took the QICore team over 500 person-hours to create the approximately 30 (very simple) QICore profiles. MITRE's recommendation is to completely change the way profiles are specified: You should be able to put your profiles into an integrated development environment like Eclipse and manage your profiles development as a project. The base resources and extensions should be brought in as fixed libraries. There should be a file hierarchy that groups similar files, e.g., /extensions, /valuesets, /profile-diffs, /examples. You should be able to use a normal text editor. The profile-diffs should be defined using the simplest possible declarations. The “build” should simply create the profile XML from the project files, and putting the result in /profiles. It should be local and self-contained. Producing documentation should be a separate process entirely, based only on the “compiled” profile XML in the /profile directory.
Summary: Editing spreadsheets is a very slow, painful way to create profiles.

Comments:
It is common that resource references should be constrained such that they resolve to a profiled resource, rather than a base resource. For example, in the US realm, wherever there is a reference to Patient, that reference should be restricted to a DAF-Patient. So any resource that references Patient will need to be profiled, to impose this restriction. For example, we have to profile NutritionOrder, whether that was in the original scope or not. Now, since ClinicalImpression refers to NutritionOrder, and we don't want to point to the unprofiled version of NutritionOrder, we have to create a profile of ClinicalImpression that restricts the reference to NutritionOrder to our new profiled version. And so on, and so on. Considering the entire network of relationships between resources in FHIR, profile developers end up having to profile most or all resources (the only exception being loosely connected or unconnected "islands" such as the billing and payment resources. Strictly speaking, any reference to "Any" immediately entails profiling every resource.) 

The fan-out problem implies creating a great many profiles (a network covering set), and changing all the resource references in those profiles. With the current tooling, this is an imposing task. For QICore, tackling the fan-out profile took about 40 person-hours of mind-numbing work.
Summary: In profiles, a better way to constrain resource references is needed.

Comments: There is no convenient way to constrain Resource(Any) types in profiles. One could conceivably list all resources and profiles, but that could be a VERY long list. In the case of QICore, the desired semantics are “use any QICore profile, but if there isn’t one for a certain resource, then use the base resource instead," but there is no way to express that.  A somewhat similar situation could occur if you wanted to restrict Reference(Observation) to only use HSPC observations. Since there is no class hierarchy among profiles, it might be necessary to list all the 500+ HSPC observations individually (?). Again, not very feasible.
Summary: No way to restrict Resource(Any)

Comments: Can the concept look up operation be achieved by using search on the ValueSet resource?
Summary: Concept look up operation may duplicate functionality

Comments: Operation URL design currently appends "$operation-name" to the end of the URL. This will complicate implementation for many developers that now need to check incoming URLs in some cases for identifiers and in others operations. While this can be achieved, it will require more cumbersome development in many popular web frameworks
Summary: Consider putting operation name in a query parameter or HTTP header
Triage Note: You'd still have to check it. I really don't see how that would be any different, and it would be more complicated in other regards. And you still have to check for other things

Existing Wording: Profiles cannot break the rules established in the base specification (e.g. if the element cardinality is 1..1 in the base specification, a profile cannot say it is 0..1, or 1..*)
Comments:
What is and what is not allowed for cardinality overrides in derived profiles is not sufficiently defined in the specification. 

"Limitations of Use" section in profiling page only gives example of 1..1 => 0..1 or 1..* not allowed, but does not give other restrictions; e.g. 0..1 => 0..*, etc. A number of FHIR profiles were created that break the rules and this will continue without a clear clarification of the rules and how they should be interpreted.

The table listed in FHIR blog, however, gives a table with rows showing cardinality for all possible values in the domain resource element against each column being cardinality specified in a derived profile.  This table makes it explicit what is and what is not allowed given the base specification.

Source: http://fhirblog.com/2014/03/26/fhir-profiles-an-overview/

FHIR spec should include the table as described in the referenced blog (or equivalent) to give a more complete description of what is and what is not allowed.
Summary: Need to list complete rules of what is allowed/not allowed for overrides in derived profiles (cardinality, type, etc.)

Comments:
Related to above issue not being documented, FHIR publishing tools are not checking for cases where the cardinality in derived profiles are not allowed. This results in publishing invalid profiles where snapshot view has the invalid cardinality values.

If only 1 is specified (max=1), then derived profiles can’t make it many. If this is the rule then it should be clearly documented and be enforced in the publish tools.

Examples:

profile: diagnosticorder-daf
DiagnosticOrder.encounter
base card: 0..1 => 0..*

profile: medicationadministration-daf
MedicationAdministration.dosage
base card: 0..1 => 0..*

The snapshot in diagnosticorder-daf shows the publisher tools allowing an invalid override to the base resource.

<snapshot>
  <element>
      <path value="DiagnosticOrder.encounter"/>
      <min value="0"/>
      <max value="*"/>
   ...
Summary: FHIR publishing tools are not validating profiles that break conformance to the base resources and are publishing artifacts that are not valid with respect to the spec.
Triage Note: Fix the tooling to validate this. I thought it was. I hope there are also ballot comments against the profiles themselves

Proposed Wording:
Table of strength showing binding in base resources in rows against strength on derived profiles in columns. This table shows what override in derived profiles is allowed and what is not allowed.

                Expl Pref'd Ext Req
Example     -       O      O    O
Preferred   X      -       O    O
Extensible  X     X       -    O
Required    X     X       X   - 

Legend:
 X = override not allowed
 O = override allowed
 - = uses same strength (no change)
Comments:
If domain resource has strength=required on the binding then derived profiles cannot loosen the strength to extensible, though you can reduce the number of codes in the value set.

This is not clearly defined in the FHIR spec in section 2.14.0.1 resulting in some profiles that break the rules.

At least 3 HL7 FHIR profiles are defined with binding=extensible on bindings declared as required in the base resource.

For example, the snapshot view for daf-diagnosticorder profile with element DiagnosticOrder.item.code shows binding as being overridden which should not be allowed.

<binding>
        <name value="USLabObservationName"/>
        <strength value="extensible"/>
        <description value="LOINC codes"/>
        <valueSetReference>
          <reference value="http://hl7.org/fhir/vs/obs-uslab-codes"/>
        </valueSetReference>
</binding>

1. DiagnosticOrder.item.code              
  DiagnosticRequests*         Required*  http://hl7.org/fhir/vs/diagnostic-requests* (base)
  USLabObservationName        Extensible http://hl7.org/fhir/vs/obs-uslab-codes

2. DiagnosticReport.name                  
  DiagnosticReportNames*      Required*  http://hl7.org/fhir/vs/report-names* (base)
  USLabObservationName        Extensible http://hl7.org/fhir/vs/obs-uslab-codes

3.Encounter.hospitalization.dischargeDisposition
  DischargeDisp*              Required*  http://hl7.org/fhir/vs/encounter-discharge-disposition* (base)
  DAFDischargeDispo           Extensible http://hl7.org/fhir/vs/daf-encounter-dischargedisposition
Summary: Need to list complete rules of what is allowed/not allowed for overrides in derived profiles with respect to binding and conformance strength.
Triage Note: Fix the tooling to validate this. I thought it was. I hope there are also ballot comments against the profiles themselves

Comments:
If domain resource has strength=required on the binding then derived profiles cannot loosen the strength to extensible, though you can reduce the number of codes in the value set.

This is uncaught in the profile publishing tooling and the profile snapshot shows the overridden binding in the published DAF profiles. Tooling needs to catch and flag such an error.

This error is resulting in at least 3 HL7 FHIR profiles are defined with binding=extensible on bindings declared as required in the base resource.

For example, the snapshot view for daf-diagnosticorder profile with element DiagnosticOrder.item.code shows binding as being overridden which should not be allowed.

<binding>
        <name value="USLabObservationName"/>
        <strength value="extensible"/>
        <description value="LOINC codes"/>
        <valueSetReference>
          <reference value="http://hl7.org/fhir/vs/obs-uslab-codes"/>
        </valueSetReference>
</binding>

1. DiagnosticOrder.item.code              
  DiagnosticRequests*         Required*  http://hl7.org/fhir/vs/diagnostic-requests* (base)
  USLabObservationName        Extensible http://hl7.org/fhir/vs/obs-uslab-codes

2. DiagnosticReport.name                  
  DiagnosticReportNames*      Required*  http://hl7.org/fhir/vs/report-names* (base)
  USLabObservationName        Extensible http://hl7.org/fhir/vs/obs-uslab-codes

3.Encounter.hospitalization.dischargeDisposition
  DischargeDisp*              Required*  http://hl7.org/fhir/vs/encounter-discharge-disposition* (base)
  DAFDischargeDispo           Extensible http://hl7.org/fhir/vs/daf-encounter-dischargedisposition
Summary: FHIR publishing tools are not validating profiles that break conformance to the base resources and are publishing artifacts that are not valid with respect to the spec.
Triage Note: Fix the tooling to validate this. I thought it was. I hope there are also ballot comments against the profiles themselves

Existing Wording: Observation.referenceRange type: string
Proposed Wording: Observation.referenceRange type: Element
Comments:
observation-spreadsheet.xml has type "string" for  referenceRange element when it has sub-elements:
Observation.referenceRange.low
Observation.referenceRange.high
Observation.referenceRange.meaning
so type must be Element.
Summary: Typo with bogus type in profile spreadsheet.

Existing Wording:
Example:

<Patient xmlns="http://hl7.org/fhir">
  <extension url="http://hl7.org/fhir/StructureDefinition/patient-clinicalTrial">
    <extension url="http://hl7.org/fhir/StructureDefinition/patient-clinicalTrialNCT">
      <valueString value="NCT01647425"/>
    </extension>
    <extension url="http://hl7.org/fhir/StructureDefinition/patient-clinicalTrialPeriod">
      <valuePeriod>
        <start value="2012-04-01"/>
        <end value="2013-09-30"/>
      </valuePeriod>
    </extension>
    <extension url="http://hl7.org/fhir/StructureDefinition/patient-clinicalTrialReason">
      <valueCodeableConcept>
        <coding>
          <system value="http://snomed.info/sct"/>
          <code value="254637007"/>
          <display value="NSCLC - Non-small cell lung cancer"/>
        </coding>
      </valueCodeableConcept>
    </extension>
  </extension>
  <extension url="http://hl7.org/fhir/StructureDefinition/patient-birthTime">
    <valueDateTime value="2012-06-07T06:12:45-05:00"/>
  </extension>
…
</Patient>
Comments:
FHIR resource in XML serialized form can be complex especially if it contains extensions of structured (type=Element) which is implemented as extensions of extensions.

Some examples were created using the full absolute URL for all extension elements but the sub-elements such be inferred by its context within the root extension. FHIR Documentation in section 1.16.0.1 show an example with sub-element extensions with only part URL identifier (e.g. url="code", url="date", etc.) but the target extension http://acme.org/fhir/StructureDefinition/trial-status is not a real extension so cannot examine the extension definition nor validate if an extension actually follows the extension definition.

In theory, a valid example could be rewritten with partial url for the sub-elements:

<Patient xmlns="http://hl7.org/fhir">
  <extension url="http://hl7.org/fhir/StructureDefinition/patient-clinicalTrial">
    <extension url="clinicalTrialNCT">
      <valueString value="NCT01647425"/>
    </extension>
    ...

Need example of nested extensions of actual extension in FHIR.
Summary: Better documentation and examples for extensions both simple primitive and more complex structures.

Existing Wording: Name:  RXO-1.2-Requested Give Code.text / RXE-2.2-Give Code.text / RXD-2.2-Dispense/Give Code.text / RXG-4.2-Give Code.text / RXA-5.2-Administered Code.text
Proposed Wording: Name:  RXO-1.2-Requested Give Code.text / RXE-2.2-Give Code.text / RXD-2.2-Dispense/Give Code.text / RXG-4.2-Give Code.text / RXA-5.2-Administered Code.text / RXC-2.2 Component Text
Comments: Added  RXC-2.2 Component Text
Summary: Added  RXC-2.2 Component Text

Existing Wording: Code:  RXO-1.1-Requested Give Code.code / RXE-2.1-Give Code.code / RXD-2.1-Dispense/Give Code.code / RXG-4.1-Give Code.code /RXA-5.1-Administered Code.code
Proposed Wording: Code:  RXO-1.1-Requested Give Code.code / RXE-2.1-Give Code.code / RXD-2.1-Dispense/Give Code.code / RXG-4.1-Give Code.code /RXA-5.1-Administered Code.code / RXC-2.1 Component Code
Comments: Added  RXC-2.1 Component Code
Summary: Added  RXC-2.1 Component Code

Existing Wording: Ingredient/Item - if substance: RXC-2-Component Code if medication: RXO-1-Requested Give Code / RXE-2-Give Code / RXD-2-Dispense/Give Code / RXG-4-Give Code / RXA-5-Administered Code
Proposed Wording: Ingredient/Item - RXC-2-Component Code if medication: RXO-1-Requested Give Code / RXE-2-Give Code / RXD-2-Dispense/Give Code / RXG-4-Give Code / RXA-5-Administered Code
Comments: Removed "if substance:"

Removed RXD-2-Dispense/Give Code

Existing Wording: dosageInstruction/additionalInstructions:  RXE-7.2-Provider's Administration Instructions.text / RXO-7.2-Provider's Administration Instructions.text / TQ1-10-Condition Text / TQ1-11-Text Instruction ?
Proposed Wording: dosageInstruction/additionalInstructions:  RXE-7.2-Provider's Administration Instructions.text / RXO-7.2-Provider's Administration Instructions.text / TQ1-10-Condition Text / TQ1-11-Text Instruction
Comments: Removed '?'
Summary: TQ1-10 and 11 would be a valid mapping to the dosage instructions element as it provides per v2 standard,  "This is a free text field that describes the conditions under which the drug is to be given."

Existing Wording: dosageInstruction/scheduled[x]: RDS:TQ1
Proposed Wording: dosageInstruction/scheduled[x]: TQ1-X / ORC Quantity/timing
Comments:
Removed reference to RDS message type and added ORC quantity/timing
Kept reference to the TQ1 segment,but specified 'X' as the field position.
Summary:
Reframing from referencing message types at this level of mapping. Mapping approach, to match v2 segments and fields to FHIR resources and elements.  Leaving message types and event triggers to the profile and status codes.
In addition, the RDS message type applies to a dispense event, not a precription order event.
Kept reference to the TQ1 segment,but specified 'X' as the field position since a collection of fields within the TQ1 segment make up the dosage scheduling instructions.

Existing Wording: dispense/validityPeriod: RXD-3-Date/Time Dispensed ? / RXD-19-Substance Expiration Date
Proposed Wording: dispense/validityPeriod: <Blank>
Comments: v2 does not offer a method for expressing this concept.
Summary: validityPeriod design explanation: This indicates the validity period of a prescription (stale dating the Prescription) It reflects the prescriber perspective for the validity of the prescription. Dispenses must not be made against the prescription outside of this period. The lower-bound of the Dispensing Window signifies the earliest date that the prescription can be filled for the first time. If an upper-bound is not specified then the Prescription is open-ended or will default to a stale-date based on regulations. Rationale: Indicates when the Prescription becomes valid, and when it ceases to be a dispensable Prescription.

Existing Wording: substitution/type: RXO-9-Allow Substitutions / RXE-9-Substitution Status?
Proposed Wording: substitution/type: RXO-9-Allow Substitutions / RXE-9-Substitution Status
Comments: removed '?'
Summary: RXE-9 is a reasonable mapping for substitution/type.

Existing Wording: substitution/reason: <Blank>
Proposed Wording: substitution/reason: RXE-9 Substition status
Comments: added RXE-9 Substition status
Summary:
RXE-9 status valuset provides insight into why a substition was made
1 Substitution not allowed by prescriber
2 Substitution allowed - patient requested product dispensed
3 Substitution allowed - pharmacist selected product dispensed
4 Substitution allowed - generic drug not in stock
5 Substitution allowed - brand drug dispensed as a generic
7 Substitution not allowed - brand drug mandated by law
8 Substitution allowed - generic drug not available in marketplace

Existing Wording: identifier: RXA-25-Administered Barcode Identifier? (V2 def'n of RXA-25 refers to the 'give' occurrence; appears not to discuss 'administer' cardinality which would seem to be 0..*)
Proposed Wording: identifier: RXA-25-Administered Barcode Identifier
Comments:
Removed "?"
Removed parenthetical v2 comment
Summary:
FHIR description for identifiy, "External identifier from non-FHIR system".  An external barcode reader likely qualifies as an external system, therefore removed the '?'.
Removal of parenthetical comment:  Does not appear that 'identifier' would address the V2 need to provide an identifier for the instance of the administration as the RXA-2 does in V2.  This may be an ommision for the medicationadministration resource, but does not appear to be handled this element therefore not recommending that RXA-2 be mapped to this element. Addressing this issue is outside of the scope of V2  mapping.

Summary: The medication statement resource is not the same as the medication administration resource, therefore all mappings to RXA have been removed.  See FHIR definition of the medication statement 'This is a record of medication being taken by a patient, or that the medication has been given to a patient where the record is the result of a report from the patient, or another clinician. '

Existing Wording: clinicalStatus maps to PRB-14
Proposed Wording: clinicalStatus maps to PRB-13
Comments:
The Condition ClinicalStatus value set has values of provisional, working, confirmed, refuted, in error etc.
In my opinion, the majority of the FHIR value set seems to better align with PRB-13, not PRB-14, although the lines are slightly blurred with in error.
PRB-13 is Confirmation Status:  confirmed, differential, provisional, rule-out
PRB 14 is Lifecycle Status:  active, active-improving, active-stable, active-worsening, inactive, resolved
Summary: Condition.clinicalStatus HL7v2 mapping
Condition category value set - add problem

Existing Wording: no HL7v2 mappings
Proposed Wording: AL1 segment
Comments: There is no mapping from the FHIR AllergyIntolerance resource to HL7v2, yet this resource presumably aligns with HL7v2 AL1 segment
Summary: AllergyIntolerance mapping to HL7v2 Al1 segment

Existing Wording: no HL7v2 mappings
Comments: The Encounter resource mapping shows episodeOfCare mapped to HL7v2 PV1-54, PV1-53, yet the EpisodeOfCare resource's mapping tab is blank
Summary: EpisodeOfCare mapping to HL7v2

Existing Wording: type maps to PV1-4-admission type
Proposed Wording: type maps to PV1-18 Patient Type
Comments:
Reason for Encounter.type mapping change: 
- Encounter.type definition is a specific type of encounter (e.g. e-mail consultation, surgical day-care, skilled nursing, rehabilitation).
- PV1-4-admission type is the circumstances under which the patient was or will be admitted (e.g. accident, emergency, L&D, Routine, Newborn,Urgent, Elective)
- PV1-18 Patient Type contains site-specific values that identify the patient -- more specific than PV1-2 Patient Class (inpatient, outpatient, emergency, obstetrics, etc)
- PV2-25-visit priority code is already mapped to Encounter.priority (e.g. emergency, urgent, elective)
Summary: Encounter.type HL7v2 mapping

Existing Wording: Person who takes responsibility for asserting the existence of the condition as part of the electronic record
Proposed Wording: Person who recorded the condition as part of the electronic record
Comments: The definition of Condition.asserter is vague -- and it is unclear whether the asserter is the who.author or who.source.  The http://hl7-fhir.github.io/w5.html implies that condition.asserter is aligned with who.author.  Update definition to reflect that the asserter is aligned with the person who recorded the condition.  Also, the Condition.asserter (who.author) should be consistent with the Condition.dateAsserted (when.recorded)
Summary: Condition.asserter definition clarification

Existing Wording: identifier.label
Proposed Wording: identifier.type
Comments: Identifier.label (text) was replaced by Identifier.type (Codeable Concept),so the example that is included within the "Introducing HL7 FHIR" page, section "Example Resource: Patient" needs to be updated
Summary: Introducing HL7 FHIR page needs to update its Patient example

Existing Wording: However all copies of the reosurce refer to the same underlying concept….
Proposed Wording: However all copies of the resource refer to the same underlying concept….
Comments: resource is misspelled
Summary: Base Resource Definition page has a misspelled word (resource)

Proposed Wording: Add cause of death
Comments:
Either (or both)
- add cause of death on the patient resource (allowing for multiple values), or
- add outcome (death) on the condition- similar to the outcome on the FamilyHistory condition
Summary: Patient Cause of Death

Existing Wording:
Condition.dateAsserted = Estimated or actual date the condition/problem/diagnosis was first detected/suspected

Condition.onset = Estimated or actual date or date-time the condition began, in the opinion of the clinician
Proposed Wording: Condition.dateAsserted = date the condition/problem/diagnosis was first documented
Comments: The definition of Condition.dateAsserted overlaps with Condition.onset, which raises questions about whether the dateAsserted is the when.recorded or when.init.  The http://hl7-fhir.github.io/w5.html implies that condition.dateAsserted is aligned with when.recorded, yet the definition reads as if it is when.init.  Update definition to reflect that the dateAsserted is aligned with when the condition was first recorded.  Also, the Condition.asserter (who.author) should be consistent with the Condition.dateAsserted (when.recorded)
Summary: Condition.dateAsserted definition clarification

Existing Wording: Identifies a style or collective of coverage issues by the underwriter, for example may be used to identify a class of coverage or employer group. May also be referred to as a Policy or Group ID
Comments: Both Coverage.group and Coverage.plan have the exact same definition.  More clarification is needed to differentiate between them
Summary: Coverage.group and Coverage.plan differentiation

Existing Wording: The OralHealthClaim is one of a suite of similar resources (VisionClaim, PharmacyClaim, ProfessionalClaim, InstitutionalClaim) which are used by providers to exchange the financial information, and supporting clinical information, regarding the provision of healthcare services.
Proposed Wording: The Claim is used by providers to exchange the financial information, and supporting clinical information, regarding the provision of healthcare services.
Comments: The Claim resource has a reference to resources that aren't in DSTU2 (OralHealthClaim, Vision, Pharmacy,Professional, and Institutional)
Summary: Claim Scope should remove references to resources not in DSTU2

Existing Wording: Coverage.dependent has type = positiveInt
Proposed Wording: Coverage.dependent has type = string
Comments: Some dependent (member) numbers are strings, not just sequential integers.  The data type for Coverage.dependent should be the same as Coverage.subscriberId
Summary: Coverage.dependentId type should support strings and/or identifiers

Existing Wording: Coverage.sequence = An optional counter for a particular instance of the identified coverage which increments upon each renewal.
Comments: Can sequence be used to communicate primary coverage vs secondary coverage?  The examples are named "General Person Primary Coverage Example" with sequence = 1 and "General Person Secondary Coverage Example", but the sequence definition doesn't sound like that was its intention.  I would like a way to convey primary vs secondary coverage
Summary: Coverage Primary and secondary sequencing for coordination of benefits

Existing Wording: Condition.clinicalStatus = provisional | working | confirmed | refuted | entered-in-error | unknown
Comments: Split out the condition's record status (in error) from clinical or confirmation Status (working, confirmed, refuted)
Summary: Condition.clinicalStatus should not convey both record status (in error) and confirmation Status (working, confirmed, refuted)

Existing Wording:
A patient encounter is further characterized by the setting in which it takes place. Amongst them are ambulatory, emergency, home health, inpatient and virtual encounters. An Encounter encompasses the lifecycle from pre-admission, the actual encounter (for ambulatory encounters), and admission, stay and discharge (for inpatient encounters). During the encounter the patient may move from practitioner to practitioner and location to location. 

Because of the broad scope of Encounter, not all elements will be relevant in all settings. For this reason, admission/discharge related information is kept in a separate Hospitalization component within Encounter. The class element is used to distinguish between these settings, which will guide further validation and application of business rules. 

There is also substantial variance from organization to organization (and between jurisdictions and countries) on which business events translate to the start of a new Encounter, or what level of aggregation is used for Encounter. For example, each single visit of a practitioner during a hospitalization may lead to a new instance of Encounter, but depending on local practice and the systems involved, it may well be that this is aggregated to a single instance for a whole hospitalization. Even more aggregation may occur where jurisdictions introduce groups of Encounters for financial or other reasons. Encounters can be aggregated or grouped under other Encounters using the partOf element. See below for examples. 

Encounter instances may exist before the actual encounter takes place to convey pre-admission information, including using Encounters elements to reflect the planned start date or planned encounter locations. In this case the status element is set to 'planned'. 

The Hospitalization component is intended to store the extended information relating to a hospitalization event. This is always expected to be the same period as the encounter itself, where this is different then another encounter is entered which captures this information which is a partOf this encounter instance
Proposed Wording: Add Encounter.hospitalization.period
Comments:
In DSTU1, there was an Encounter.hospitalization.period that was removed in DSTU2.  The Encounter.period is not sufficient since an encounter could start in the emergency department and then progress into a hospitalization.  Having a single Encounter.period doesn't indicate both the arrival date (in the ED) and also the date when the actual admission to inpatient took place.

The scope section is contradictory when it acknowledges "There is also substantial variance from organization to organization (and between jurisdictions and countries) on which business events translate to the start of a new Encounter, or what level of aggregation is used for Encounter.  For example, each single visit of a practitioner during a hospitalization may lead to a new instance of Encounter, but depending on local practice and the systems involved, it may well be that this is aggregated to a single instance for a whole hospitalization" yet then follows by saying "The Hospitalization component is intended to store the extended information relating to a hospitalization event. This is always expected to be the same period as the encounter itself, where this is different then another encounter is entered which captures this information which is a partOf this encounter instance."

As a side note, the DAF Meaningful Use Data Element Mapping does need both an Encounter.period and Encounter.hospitalization.period
Summary: Encounter.hospitalization.period

Comments:
Search-specific page needs to clarify what URL POST should be supported against. It’s clear in the http page, but not in the search-specific page.

Similarly, the search page should describe behavior around ETag, Last-Modified headers (mentioned on http page)

Under “identity”, it states that if ports differ, the identity of the resource differs, but specifically mentions that http is equivalent to https. This conflicts. 
Also, http and https should not be considered identical, there is no digital certificate or authority to verify that the http site is the same host/data provider as the https site.
Triage Note: need discussion. There may be no resolution to http/https cause we clearly can't say that they must be different. Though note that just cause we say they identity is the same doesn’t mean that you mus trust them the same

Comments:
The media types defined by FHIR are:

application/xml+fhir

application/json+fhir


These naming of these media types do not follow RESTful conventions or the naming conventions of proper media types. fhir is not a proper media type suffix. Take a look at the list of IANA registered suffixes -- you will see that FHIR does not fit into this: http://www.iana.org/assignments/media-type-structured-suffix/media-type-structured-suffix.xhtml


These media types should be named something like:

application/vnd.hl7.fhir+xml

application/vnd.hl7.fhir+json

The hl7.fhir subtype should be registered to the IANA under the application type and vnd tree per http://www.iana.org/assignments/media-types/media-types.xhtml
Triage Note: sigh. Discussion. What a mess this question is. If we change it, we better not ever change it again

Comments: AllergyIntolerance.event is confusing as documentation states that it’s really an event or symptom representation, and not an event reporting system. Rename for clarity? In the future, will there be links to AdverseEvent? “This resource represents a condition of susceptibility to a substance, with a list of supporting events and/or symptoms, and has no direct relationship to an event reporting framework; this will be re-assessed when Adverse Event reporting resource(s) and/or profiles are added to FHIR (not expected to happen prior to DSTU 2)”

Further, applications may only want to trend vitals or display laboratory results. The only way to currently do this is to understand the entirety of the coding system the code is tied to. One option is to make the observation classification a first class element that is populated explicitly by the source system whereas another option would be a FHIR-defined value set that defines the scope of which codes universally represent the top 200 labs (for example). 

The level of granularity requested is:
laboratory
vitalSign
imaging
measurement
assessment
socialHistory
unknown

Allow type to search parameters for Observation

Comments:
The FHIR API uses underscores for several fields and resources. For example, _history and _search are RESTful resources prefixed with underscores. Similarly, parameters like _format, _count, and _since use underscores.

We cannot find any documentation or guidances as to when underscores are used in a RESTful resource or parameter name.

We suspect that the underscore prefixed parameters are attempting to distinguish from attributes of the Resource. However, explicit documentation regarding the use of underscores in parameters would be appreciated. This would ensure that those making proposals/change to the FHIR REST API follow a consistent naming strategy/pattern.

We are not sure of the underscore usage for the _history and _search resources. They are not FHIR Resources (though they are REST resources) so perhaps that is the intended distinction? Again, having explicit documentation as to the meaning of the underscore will help those making future proposals/changes to the FHIR API to follow a consistent naming strategy/pattern.
Summary: RESTful special characters
Triage Note: well, we can add documentation about that

AllergyIntolerance.event.severity = Clinical assessment of the severity of the reaction event as a whole, potentially considering multiple different manifestations
Comments: How common is it to capture severity at the event (reaction) level as opposed to capturing it at the allergyIntolerance level?  If a system only has severity at the allergy level, does it get repeated for each event (reaction)?  Assuming criticality is different than severity, should there be a new severity added at the allergyIntolerance level?
Summary: Add AllergyIntolerance.severity

Existing Wording:
informationSource = The person who provided the information about the taking of this medication
dateAsserted = The date when the medication statement was asserted by the information source
reasonNotGiven = A code indicating why the medication was not taken
Scope = the summarization of a patient's "active medications" in a patient profile
Comments: MedicationStatement scope implies a summarization of all active medications (which could be either inpatient or outpatient medications).  The reasonNotGiven is most relevant for inpatient (medicationadministration) medications, which supports the scope of the MedicationStatement including inpatient (administered) medications.  However, the EMR is generally only asking the patient about compliance (wasNotGiven) for outpatient/home prescriptions due to the lack of visibility to patient compliance with those home medications.  In the inpatient setting, when clinicians are administering medications, there is no need to ask the patient for their compliance statement (since the medication administration record serves as evidence that the medication was given).  Thus, many inpatient (administered) medications won't have an explicit informationSource and dateAsserted, but rather inpatient orders will have an actual medicationprescription and corresponding medicationadministrations.  The scope implies the MedicationStatement resource is intended to cover inpatient medication orders that were administered by the provider, which means there is some ambiguity in the informationSource and dateAsserted.  EMRs will track the medicationprescription and medicationadministration, but do EMRs generally document compliance beyond that?  Will there be an informationSource and/or dateAsserted or will it be implied through MedStatement.informationSource = MedPrescription.prescriber and MedStatement.dateAsserted = MedPrescription.dateWritten?  I want the ability to convey the full list of active medications, but I would like to decouple this from medication compliance (wasNotGiven, reasonNotGiven, etc).
Summary: Decouple active medication list from medication statement (compliance / wasNotGiven)

Comments:
If there’s an application written to query/update MedicationStatement and that application is opened while the patient is actually admitted to the hospital, and the user intends to update the known patient meds, the application probably doesn’t want to inadvertently attempt to update an ongoing inpatient medication. How does the application know that it should write a new patient documented med vs. updating one that was returned?   The MedicationStatement.informationSource is used to identify the person who provided the information about the taking of this medication, but that doesn’t necessarily identify whether the medication was recorded or prescribed.  Proposed change:  Add an attribute to allow consumers to know which MedicationStatements are recorded (based on patient statement) or prescribed (infer from administration).  For example, that could be a boolean (similar to Immunization.recorded) or a reference to the originating MedicationPrescription/MedAdmin, then:
* If there is a link/reference to the originating MedicationPrescription or MedicationAdministration, then the MedicationStatement can't be updated because it is a clinically documented fact that the med was given (prescribed/ordered).
* If there is NO link/reference to the originating MedicationPrescription or Medication Administration, then that MedicationStatement can be updated because it is based on a statement from the patient (recorded).
Summary: MedicationStatement updates

Comments: More examples would be helpful to see when each Timing element is applicable -- when to use timing.event, when to use timing.repeat.count, etc.
Summary: More timing examples

Existing Wording:
MedicationStatement.status = A code specifying the state of the statement. Generally this will be in-progress or completed state

Value Set In Progress = The medication is still being taken
Comments: Is MedicationStatement.status the status of the medication order/prescription or the status of the compliance statement (taking or not)?  The definition sounds like it is the definition of the statement (compliance taking med) whereas the value set sounds like it is the status of the MedicationPrescription itself (i.e. in-progress = The medication is still being taken)
Summary: MedicationStatement.status clarification

Existing Wording: Timing.repeat.duration= For some events the duration is part of the definition of the event (e.g. IV infusions). For others, it's part of the timing specification (e.g. exercise).
