Summary: IV Infusion timing

Existing Wording: Research questionnaires/Clinical research forms (CRFs)
Comments: These concepts need to be split.  CRFs is a reserved word in context to clinical trial, data collection.

Existing Wording: Differential table: Moderate or severe AE might need consultation, better to have the consultation extension. Note that consultations may not always exist or be available
Proposed Wording: Add consultation extension.
Comments: In real world, consultation is pretty common.

Existing Wording: Snapshot table: Need to add who validate the AE in addtion to who create: Validation of AE. Note that validations may not always exist or be available
Proposed Wording: Validation of AE.
Comments: Some AE might need to be validated or confrimed.

Existing Wording: Note: All URLs (and ids that form part of the URL) defined by this specification are case sensitive.
Proposed Wording: Note: All URLs (and ids that form part of the URL) defined by this specification are case sensitive. Servers can implement URLs either as case sensitive or insensitive
Comments: Case insensitive URLs provide  more permissive support for requests, and are inline with the W3C guidelines that the implementation of URL paths is left up to the server
Summary: Case Insensitivity proposal for URLs
Triage Note: Disagree. We had case insensitivity, and this actually forces implementation of URL paths on the server, so we changed it. Client must conserve case, and get the case correct.

Existing Wording: Using HTTPS is optional, but all production exchange of healthcare data SHOULD use SSL and additional security as appropriate. See HTTP Security for further information.
Proposed Wording: Using HTTPS is required. All production exchange of healthcare data SHALL use SSL and additional security as appropriate. See HTTP Security for further information.
Comments: HTTPS is not a significant burden for servers or clients to support, and mandating that HTTPS is used in all FHIR exchanges will promote the development of clients and servers toward using HTTPS, as well as make FHIR more secure
Summary: All FHIR Data Exhange should be via HTTPS.
Triage Note: No. It's actually a serious burden - not the computation, but the certificate management. And there are cases where there's no need for it. There's no reason for FHIR to get into this space; people can use HTTP if they want

Existing Wording: Other than testing systems, FHIR servers should authenticate the clients.
Proposed Wording: Other than testing systems, FHIR servers SHALL authenticate the clients.
Summary: FHIR Data Exchange should be authenticated.
Triage Note: This is not an appropriate rule to make in the base specification. There are a number of use cases where there is no need to authenticate the client - for instance, when not dealing with patient data (public knowledge registries). Also, it's not clear whether OAuth/Smart-On-Fhir is 'authenticating the clients' nor should we get into that debate. SHOULD is perfectly appropriate at this level

Existing Wording: The choice of whether to return 403 or 404 depends upon the specific situation and specific local policies, regulations, and laws.
Proposed Wording: Servers SHALL respond with 403 responses when a client is not authorized.
Comments: 403 Responses ensure that a PI disclosure to an unauthorized client do not occur, and are standard practice for common authorization solutions. See Comment #2 for rationale on SHALL versus SHOULD.
Summary: Require 403 Response for Unauthorized Access.
Triage Note: Again, no. There are cases where disclosure is desired. There's not a one size fits all policy here. We should leave the existing policy

Existing Wording: The client can indicate whether the entire resource is returned using the HTTP return preference:
Proposed Wording: Servers SHALL return the entire resource content as it is represented in their system.
Comments: Servers may transform content received from the client and that server-native representation of content should be conveyed to clients
Summary: Server Representation of Content should be returned on Create and Update
Triage Note: We added this at the express request of implementers, and there's no reason to take it out. Servers are not required to support it, so I don't see what the issue is

Existing Wording: However in order to support various implementation limitations, servers SHOULD support the optional _format parameter to specify alternative response formats by their MIME-types. This parameter allows a client to override the header value when it is unable to set it correctly due to internal limitations. For the_format parameter, the values "xml", "text/xml", "application/xml", and "application/xml+fhir" SHALL be interpreted to mean the normative XML format defined by FHIR and "json", "application/json" and "application/json+fhir" SHALL be interpreted to mean the informative JSON format.
Proposed Wording: Clients SHALL indicate their content type through standard W3C headers
Comments: We have W3C standards for making this kind of request, and modern web browsers and devices all support the ability to set HTTP content-type headers. This feels extraneous and an unnecessary burden on the server. We should remove it.
Summary: Remove suppport for _format
Triage Note: We'd love to remove it, but there's still clients that don't support content type headers (yay XSLT). If we take away _format, then we kiss those implementation environments goodbye

Existing Wording: Servers SHOULD return an ETag header with the versionId and a Content-Location header with the response which is the full version specific url (see vread below) and a Last-Modified header.
Proposed Wording: Servers SHOULD return an ETag header with the versionId and a Content-Location header with the response which is the full version specific url (see vread below) and a Last-Modified header. If servers do not support full versioning, the content-location header SHOULD be populated with the logical ID URL.
Comments: Provide additional clarification on behavior when versioning is not supported
Summary: Clarify content-location for Reads without Versioning support

Existing Wording: The server MAY include a response body containing anOperationOutcome resource with hints and warnings about the resource; if one is sent it SHALL not include any errors.
Proposed Wording: The server MAY include a response body containing a bundle with additional OperationOutcome resource(s) with hints and warnings about the resource; if one is sent it SHALL not include any errors.
Comments: The proposed wording is one potential approach on how to return content with resource(s) and OperationOutcomes, but other approaches may also have merit. The main goal is to provide a clear indication of how OO and resource(s) can both be returned, as the current approach is ambiguous. This statement is included elsewhere and should be updated in those locations as well.
Summary: Clarification on Resource + OperationOutcome responses

Existing Wording: The conditional update operation allows a client to update an existing resource based on some identification criteria, rather than by logical id.
Proposed Wording: Remove
Comments: The standard should not include support for conditional updates. This action between a server and client should occur as a Search + Update, as it gives clients the opportunity to vealidate the resource they are looking to update prior to modifying content within the server
Summary: Remove support for conditional updates.
Triage Note: It is added to support environments where the client can't do search + updated (e.g. in a transaction). Servers are not required to support it, but some clients can't function with out it

Existing Wording: The conditional delete operation allows a client to update an existing resource based on some identification criteria, rather than by logical id.
Proposed Wording: Remove
Comments: The standard should not include support for conditional deletes. This action between a server and client should occur as a Search + Delete, as it gives clients the opportunity to validate the resource they are looking to delete prior to modifying content within the server
Summary: Remove support for conditional deletes.
Triage Note: It is added to support environments where the client can't do search + updated (e.g. in a transaction). Servers are not required to support it, but some clients can't function with out it

Existing Wording: The conditional create operation allows a client to create a new resource only if some equivalent resource does not already exist on the server. The client defines what equivalence means in this case by supplying a FHIR search query in an If-None-Existheader as shown:
Proposed Wording: Remove
Comments: The standard should not include support for conditional creates This action between a server and client should occur as a Search + Creates, as it gives clients the opportunity to validate the resource they are looking to create prior to modifying content within the server
Summary: Remove support for conditional creates.
Triage Note: It is added to support environments where the client can't do search + updated (e.g. in a transaction). Servers are not required to support it, but some clients can't function with out it

Existing Wording: The server SHALL populate the meta.versionId and meta.lastUpdatedwith the new correct values.
Proposed Wording: The server SHOULD populate the meta.versionId and meta.lastUpdatedwith the new correct values if the server supports versioning.
Comments: This clause should be conditional on the server support of versioning
Summary: Make version metadata support on Creates conditional on version support by servers
Triage Note: hmm investigate. Agree that we may have to adjust this wording a little.

Proposed Wording: This interaction searches a set of resources based on some filter criteria. Servers SHALL support seearch via a POST based search: POST  [base]/[type]/_search or POST [base]/[type] and submit their search parametes via x-form-urlencoded values
Comments: Searches on all resources have the potential to expose PHI and PII within the URL querystring - Patient search is one example, but most resources could potentially contain the protected information in their querystring. While this querystring is encrypted under HTTPS, the majority of web and proxy servers log the URL in unencrypted server logs that don't have the same data security processes that production healthcare databases employ. To avoid the risk, FHIR should support POST-based search via x-form-urlencoded queries.
Summary: Exclusively support POST for searches
Triage Note: Disagree. There's no way we're taking GET based search away just because of the common - but erroneous - belief that the body isn't logged less securely than the URL.

Existing Wording: For example, to retrieve all the observation resources for a particular LOINC code associated with a particular encounter:  GET [base]/Encounter/23423445/Observation?code=2951-2  {&_format=[mime-type]}
Proposed Wording: For example, to retrieve all the observation resources for a particular LOINC code associated with a particular encounter:  GET [base]/Encounter/23423445/Observation?code=2951-2  {&_format=[mime-type]}
Comments: This is an incredibly powerful way to support expressive queries. We'd suggest that you define some of the specifics further, wither in this section or in the Compartment documentation, to express how to query for related resources via variant searching
Summary: Further clarification for variant searches within compartments
Triage Note: What kind of additional things to define? Is this just a request for more examples?

Existing Wording: An ETag header SHALL be returned with the conformance resource. The value of the header SHALL change if the conformance statement itself changes.
Proposed Wording: An ETag header SHOULD be returned with the conformance resource. The value of the header SHOULD change if the conformance statement itself changes.
Comments: Etags are not required on other resources, and should not be required for this resource; doing so would require special handling for the server to treat conformance differently than other resources.
Summary: Make Etag support for Conformance optional
Triage Note: Don't know; it is different to all the other resources. I'm not persauded that this is a problrem

Existing Wording: Each entry SHALL contain a transaction, and, if the entry.transaction.methodis a PUT or a POST, a resource. The entry SHALL contain the resource state at the conclusion of the operation.
Proposed Wording: The entry SHALL contain the resource state of when the resource version was created.
Comments: Servers may version resources outside of interactions which occur via the FHIR methods, and may track these updates as versions of resources. To support that b ehaviour, transaction should not be a required element in the history response.
Summary: Remove Transaction requirement for History interaction
Triage Note: Agree that transaction should be optional. Don't agree with the specific wording - need to word smith it a little

Existing Wording: For this reason, servers SHOULD change the resource as little as possible. However due to the variability that exists within healthcare, this specification allows that servers MAY alter the resource on create/update.
Proposed Wording: This specification allows that servers MAY alter the resource on create/update.
Comments: FHIR servers will be implemented within EMRs and other HIT applications, where application actions outside of the API may constitue a large majority of the interaction with FHIR resources. We should therefore remove the SHOULD stipulation of this
Summary: Remove SHOULD stipulation for Server Content Manipulation
Triage Note: Don't agree with the change, but need to clarify that changes from other sources than FHIR interface aren't the intention of the should

Comments: We suggest that we make more specific guidelines for how to handle resource integrity and lifecycle management. We suggest that we give clear guidelines for at minimum read and other resource level interactions on merged content, and search behavior when resource identifiers are used as parameters. For the former case, we suggest performing content redirection where possible, or if not possible, to provide specific OperationOutcomes to indicate content modification caused the HTTP error. For the latter, we request guidance on specific search outcomes when resource identifiers used in the search parameters have been merged, deleted, or otherwise modified, and suggest additional OperationOutcomes specifying these particular conditions
Summary: Transaction Integrity Guidelines in Read and Search

Existing Wording: Both client and server systems SHOULD clearly document how transaction integrity is handled. DSTU TODO: how?
Proposed Wording: Both client and server systems SHALL clearly document how transaction integrity is handled through one of two ways. (1) If servers manage and track resource transaction integrity, servers indicate that they will redirect to target resources of merged content on resource-level interactions, and (2) if servers do not manage and track, they should indicate this through operationoutcome
Comments: We should give clear guidelines for how to support transactional integrity by servers. We've defined two general strategies, but will likely need to update the conformance resource to support the tracking of this information
Summary: Guidelines for Resource Integrity Management within Conformance
Triage Note: Don't agree with the proposed wording, but more discussion is needed.

Existing Wording: When populating the organization and location hierarchies there is often not a clear distinction between these 2, however to assist in making the decision, Locations are always used for recording where a service occurs, and hence where encounters and observations are associated. The Organization property on these resources may not be the location where the service took place.
Comments: There is some ambiguity regarding when to use a Location vs. an Organization (encounter or observation could reasonably use either one).  Recommend that there is more explicit language to determine when to use one vs. the other so that clients know what to expect.
Summary: Clarify use case for Location vs. Organization.

Existing Wording: This specification does not specify merge functionality: if multiple patient records are found to be duplicates, they can be linked together, as described above.
Comments: This language leaves multiple alternatives for server behavior when receiving a merged-off resource ID for a patient.  Suggest defining required behavior to redirect to current patient with a notification of content location change.
Summary: Require server behavior for merged patients.

Existing Wording: An address in any kind of address/part of the patient
Proposed Wording: Remove
Comments: Address is a valid search parameter, but it is not granular enough; it is difficult for a server to search on a string that could be any part of an address.  Address should be its own type made up of line address, city, state, etc. See existing GForge tracker item 3918
Summary: Make the address search parameter its own type with subdivisions rather than simply a string.

Existing Wording: Condition.location: the anatomical location where the condition manifests itself.
Proposed Wording: Condition.area
Comments: Location is generally used to refer to the patient's physical location, not a site on their body.  While Condition.location is a list holder for Condition.location.site[x], the term is still likely to remind people of physical location instead.
Summary: Inconsistent use of term "location" between Condition and other resources

Existing Wording: ReferralRequest.fulfillmentTime requirements: Use cases: (1) to indicate that the requested service is not to happen before a specified date (2) to indicate that the requested service must happen before a specified date (3) to indicate that the requested service must happen during the specified dates ("low" and "high" values).
Proposed Wording: ReferralRequest.fulfillmentTime requirements: Use cases: (1) to indicate that the requested service is not to happen before a specified date, and saving the start date in Period.start (2) to indicate that the requested service must happen before a specified date, and saving the end date in Period.end (3) to indicate that the requested service must happen during the specified dates ("low" and "high" values).
Comments: Clarify which field to use for cases 1 and 2 in ReferralRequest.fulfillmentTime
Summary: Unclear wording in field requirements in ReferralRequest

Existing Wording: The request message consists of a Bundle identified by the type "message", with the first resource in the bundle being a MessageHeader resource.
Proposed Wording: The request message consists of a Bundle identified by the type "message", and SHALL contain a MessageHeader resource.
Comments: Ordered arrays are not allowed in JSON, so the implementation of this specification should not depend on order
Summary: Bundle Order in Messages Does not Make Sense in JSON Format

Comments: Why not use HTML

Existing Wording:
Operations can also be executed asynchronously. In this case, the requester sends a message requesting that an operation be executed, and the destination system subsequently sends a message back with the results of the operation.

Given the increased complexity of the asynchronous use case, the implementation has increased complexity. As a summary, asynchronous operations are performed like this:
Proposed Wording: Operations can also be executed asynchronously. In this case, the requester sends a message requesting that an operation be executed, along with an additional parameter in the querystring to define a callback URL. If the Operation request is accepted, the server returns a 202 in the response. When the Operation completes, the server will POST the response content to the specified URL
Comments: Using messaging for asynchronous operations is overly complex. We propose a callback-based scheme similar to x-callback-url which is a well-established means for asynchronous operations over HTTP.
Summary: Change Asynchronous Operation execution to use Callback URLs

Existing Wording: If there are no parameters with complex types (including resources) to the operation, and the operation is idempotent (see HTTP specification definition of idempotent), the operation may be invoked by performing an HTTP GET operation where all the parameters are appended to the URL in the search portion of the URL (e.g. after the "?"). Servers SHALL support this method of invocation.
Proposed Wording: If there are no parameters with complex types (including resources) to the operation, and the operation is idempotent (see HTTP specification definition of idempotent), the operation may be invoked by performing an HTTP GET operation where all the parameters are appended to the URL in the search portion of the URL (e.g. after the "?"). Servers SHOULD support this method of invocation.
Comments: GET invocation is a convenience method and should not be a requirement for servers to support.
Summary: Remove GET Operation Invocation Requirement for servers
Triage Note: Well, if servers don't support it, it stops being convenient - and a lot of clients will use the convenience methods. Is it a problem to support it?

Existing Wording: Once assembled into a bundle, the document is immutable - its content can never be changed, and the document id can never be reused. Note that the document may be represented in either XML or JSON, and interconverted between these or have its character encoding changed, all the while remaining the same document. However the content (the set of attested resources, and their order) and the presentation of the document cannot change. Any additional documents derived from the same composition SHALL have a different document id.
Proposed Wording: Once assembled into a bundle, the document is immutable - its content can never be changed, and the document id can never be reused. Note that the document may be represented in either XML or JSON, and interconverted between these or have its character encoding changed, all the while remaining the same document. However the directly referenced content within the document cannot change. Any additional documents derived from the same composition SHALL have a different document id.
Comments: Indirectly referenced resources not included in the document maay necessarily be modified on the document server after the document is created. Clarified the wording to note that only directly referenced resources cannot change
Summary: Clarify Document Immutability for Indirect Resource References

Existing Wording: All documents have the same structure: a Bundle of resources of type "document" that has a Composition resource as the first resource in the bundle, followed by a series of other resources referenced from the Composition resource that provides guidance on how they fit together.
Proposed Wording: All documents have the same structure: a Bundle of resources of type "document" that has a Composition resource, as well as other resources referenced from the Composition resource, that provides guidance on how they fit together.
Comments: JSON arrays cannot guarantee order, so functionality in the specification should not depend on ordered content.
Summary: Document Composition Ordering is not Compatible with JSON
Triage Note: not true. JSON arrays are all about order.

Existing Wording: Additional events may be defined elsewhere, though this specification does not yet define how. DSTU: Input on this is sought during the trial use period.
Comments: Input on event types: FHIR currently defines an OperationDefinition to define operations, so a MessagingDefinition could also be created. This feels overly constraining though. Why not use a specific ValueSet resource to define system events?
Summary: Suggestions for Event definition via ValueSet Resource

Comments: FHIR Messaging architecture doesn't define a publish subscribe model on top of resources, and should. Subscriptions should take one or more events to subscribe to, an additional set of criteria to filter events, and optionally, a callback URL to execute when events occurred. Servers could respond with a URL to query for notifications, if the POST-based framework isn't sustainable.
Summary: Leverage Messaging Architecture for Pub-Sub Model in FHIR

Comments: This part of the specification has little information about how services should be implemented, and is only a set of best practices. There's little value in keeping this content.
Summary: Remove Services #1 Page From Specification

Comments: This part of the specification has little information about how services should be implemented, and is only a set of best practices and fluff about FHIR. There's little value in keeping this content.
Summary: Remove Services #2 Page From Specification

Comments: As it stands, the services component within the specification are in danger of becoming unused and irrelevant. We request that SOA should define practical implementation guidelines for implementers to build services. Without that information, few outside of the SOA community have any reason to investigate further
Summary: FHIR and SOA Needs to be Practical, not Theoretical

Existing Wording: In the simplest case, a search is executed by performing a GET operation in the RESTful framework:  GET [base]/[resourcetype]?name=value&… For this RESTful search (see definition in RESTful API), the parameters are a series of name=[value] pairs encoded in the URL or as an application/x-www-form-urlencoded submission for a POST.
Proposed Wording: In the simplest case, a search is executed by performing a POST operation in the RESTful framework:  POST [base]/[resourcetype] For this RESTful search (see definition in RESTful API), the parameters are a series of name=[value] pairs encoded as an application/x-www-form-urlencoded submission for a POST.
Comments: Only POST should be supported on searches. Due to the types of data that may be exposed in querystrings, FHIR should restrict both clients and servers to support x-form-urlencoded POSTs.
Summary: Only support POST for FHIR RESTful Search
Triage Note: Disagree. There's no way we're taking GET based search away just because of the common - but erroneous - belief that the body isn't logged less securely than the URL.

Existing Wording: The search parameter _language refers to the base language of the resource:  GET [base]/Composition?_language=fr This search finds any composition with a designated language of French. Note that this is the claimed language of the resource, not the actual language of the content.
Proposed Wording: Remove
Comments: We propose that there is little value inherent to supporting language queries, and that the parameter should be removed from a default
Summary: Remove _language query parameter support
Triage Note: Just cause there's little value in USA doesn't mean that there's little value in other contexts (e.g. Europe). Check with Europeans about this; remove if there's no desire for it

Existing Wording: Parameters are defined per resource, and their names may additionally specify a modifier as a suffix, separated from the parameter name by a colon. Modifiers are:
Proposed Wording: Parameters are defined per resource, and their values may additionally specify a modifier as a prefix separated from the parameter value by a colon.
Comments: Modifieres should modify content, not the parameter name. Modifying the parameter name breaks the convention of querystrings, and makes parsing te querystring a process that can't be completed by common API frameworks
Summary: Modifiers should modify content, not names.
Triage Note: sigh. This is hard, because if you modify the parameter content, you increase the woe related to escapes etc. I'm not sure how this breaks conventions realted to queey strings and means that they can't be completed by common API frameworks - we all use them. Just that we do work on top of them

Existing Wording: The prefixes >, >=, <=, and < may be used on the parameter value, and have the usual meaning (note that "=" must be URL-encoded in the value in a URL). Examples:
Proposed Wording: The prefixes ), ], [, and ( may be used on the parameter value, and have the usual meaning. Examples:
Comments: We agree with the concept of providing ranges within numerical parameter types, but suggest using another well-known method for suggesting ranges, to avoid url-escaping.
Summary: Alternative suggestion for Numerical Ranges
Triage Note: discussion in committee. Technically, I don't think this avoids the problem - and may make it worse due to lack of clarity about whether they have to be escaped or not - but I like the idea

Existing Wording: A date parameter searches on a date/time or period. The prefixes >, >=, <=, and < may be used on the parameter value, and have the usual meaning.
Proposed Wording: A date parameter searches on a date/time or period. The prefixes ), ], [, and ( may be used on the parameter value, and have the usual meaning.
Comments: We agree with the concept of providing ranges within date parameter types, but suggest using another well-known method for suggesting ranges, to avoid url-escaping.
Summary: Alternative suggestion for Date Ranges
Triage Note: discussion in committee. Technically, I don't think this avoids the problem - and may make it worse due to lack of clarity about whether they have to be escaped or not - but I like the idea

Existing Wording: For [parameter]=!=[date], the requirement is that the search interval does not fully contain the time of the target. i.e. [parameter]=!=2013-01-14 includes 2013-01-15T00:00 but not 2013-01-14T00:00 or 2013-01-14T10:00
Comments: "!=" is declared in this paragraph, but is not mentioned as a valid modifier of dates. Is it meant to? If so, we suggest using "!" on it's own.
Summary: Clarification on "!=" for Dates
Triage Note: I don't mind, but it depends on the previous two proposals

Existing Wording: In order to save a client from doing a series of search operations, reference parameters may be "chained" by appending them with a period (.) followed by the name of a search parameter defined for the target resource. This can be done recursively, following a logical path through a graph of related resources, separated by ".". For instance, given that the resource DiagnosticReport has a search parameter namedsubject, which is usually a reference to a Patient resource, and the Patient resource includes a parameter name which searches on patient name, then the search  GET [base]/DiagnosticReport?subject.name=peter
Proposed Wording: In order to save a client from doing a series of search operations, reference parameters may be "chained" by prefixing the parameter value with the name of a search parameter defined for the target resource, proceeded by a ":". This can be done recursively, following a logical path through a graph of related resources, separated by ".". For instance, given that the resource DiagnosticReport has a search parameter namedsubject, which is usually a reference to a Patient resource, and the Patient resource includes a parameter name which searches on patient name, then the search  GET [base]/DiagnosticReport?subject=name:peter
Comments: In line with feedback regarding modifiers, we similarly propose that chained parameters be implemented wthin the query parameter value string, in a similar manner to the proposed modifier syntax, to support the client needing to parse the values while still understanding the base parameter.
Summary: Chained parameters should modify content, not names.
Triage Note: Again, we get stuck in inventing ever more complicated escaping syntax in the value. I think this is a negative change that complicates things more

Comments: We already have well defined query syntaxes for structured data, lke SQL, or LINQ. Why not stand on the shoulders of giants and not reinvent the wheel?
Summary: Improve Operators to Use an Existing Query Syntax
Triage Note: What is defined here is based closely on SCIM / oData. Not sure what specific proposals Sean has in mind here

Comments: Type' isn't the best choice to describe what the property pertains to. 'Identity' or 'Identifier' seems more appropriate.
Summary: Modify Name of Substance.Type Property

Comments: Substance should have an additional 'class' property that defines the general class of the substance (allergens are often grouped into meds, foods, environments, etc., as an example). This 'class' can be defined in a FHIR ValueSet
Summary: Add class property tosubstance.

Existing Wording: Patient's nominated care provider
Comments: Care provider is a more complex concept than the current definition.  This could represent a patient's PCP, preferred pharmacist, etc.  At very least, the careProvider needs a "type" value to account for provider roles within a care team.
Summary: Type careProvider to account for roles.

Comments: The priority of an appointment should be represented by a defined value set, rather than an integer "pointer" to the iCal standard for consistency and completeness
Summary: Update type of Priority.

Existing Wording: participant.actor is currently 0..1
Proposed Wording: Believe that this should be 1..1
Comments: the use of participant needs further definition and clarification. Please define the required elements for each participant in the list - a participant without an actor is meaningless
Summary: participant.actor should be required

Existing Wording: Schedule.actor has resource type of "Any"
Proposed Wording: Update to match to participant.actor
Comments: The type of actor should be limited to resources which can realistically be scheduled, not any resource. This should be consistent with the types of actors supported by Appointment.
Summary: Schedule.actor has resource type of "Any"

Comments: List and Bundleshould be consolidated into a single resource. List on it's own does not provide enough benefit to warrant being a resource separate from Bundle.
Summary: Consolidate List and Bundle into single resource.

Existing Wording: A Composition is also the basic structure from which FHIR Documents - immutable bundles with attested narrative - are built. A single logical composition may be associated with a series of derived documents, each of which is a frozen copy of the composition. Note: EN 13606 uses the term "Composition" to refer to a single commit to an EHR system, and offers some common examples: a consultation note, a progress note, a report or a letter, an investigation report, a prescription form and a set of bedside nursing observations. These logical examples are all valid uses of a Composition resource, but it is not required that all the resources are updated in a single commit.
Proposed Wording: A Composition is the basic structure from which FHIR Documents - immutable bundles with attested narrative - are built. A single logical composition may be associated with a series of derived documents, each of which is a frozen copy of the composition.
Comments: Compositions as they relate to documents are conceptually different than notes, and should be treated differently. We propose to limit the scoe of the composition resource to documents, and separately add a 'Note' resource to capture concepts relating to unstructured documentation.
Summary: Limit Scope of Composition Resource to Documents

Existing Wording: it marks it as processed using the tag ?? and the meta operation (POST to [base]/[type]/[id]/_meta where [id] is MTA id for the source message)
Proposed Wording: it marks it as processed (e.g. by using a receiver-defined tag and the meta operation (POST to [base]/[type]/[id]/_meta where [id] is MTA id for the source message))
Comments: using tag is just one way of doing this, using some Workflow oriented resource (yet to be defined) may be another.
Sugest to add comparison with relatd non-HL7 specs as well, notably DICOM

In IHE XDS some of the DocumentEntry elements are explicitely marked as being listed for 'provenance reasons'. This leads to duplication of elements between DocumentReference and Provenance (e.g. author). If this desirable, suggest to add wording to describe relationship between DocumentReference and Provenance.

add code for 'legalAuthentuicator'. When mapping the XDS matada items (those explicitely listed as being there for Provenance reasons) to the Provenance resource, both author as well as legalAuthenticator are listed.
The value set for .entity.type is listed as Required and is composed of FHIR resources, I think this is an error and should be "extensible"

Given that the agent.type is allowed to be an organization and that the definition of agent explicitly allows an organization, the fact that organization is missing from the list of allowed reference types is rather a glaring omission.
Add 'entity' and 'entitytype' as query parameters for provenance.

Existing Wording: 7. The source system can check on the status of messages and track responses using the same approaches as listed above for the receiver system.
Comments: Add option for a receiver to send responses to mailbox endpoint of the source
Add link element, sith similar functionality as Patient.link. Patient, provider, Practtioners tend to be registries that are most often well-managed enough to merit linking.
Add link element, sith similar functionality as Patient.link. Patient, provider, Practtioners tend to be registries that are most often well-managed enough to merit linking.
A formal registry of profiles and extensions is important before FHIR is finalized. I couldn't locate a discussion of a registry or commitments to completing one before FHIR is normative.
Summary:
A pilot project within DoD/VA IPO reviewed 3 profiles on Vital Signs, including C-CDA on FHIR. It became very clear that without a robust registry profile proliferation will occur. This proliferation will require each site and vendor to develop their own FHIR profiles and will recreate the HL7 V2 problem, customization for each new site.

Requirements may necessitate differences but it would be helpful to designers to highlight differences so only meaningful changes are introduced.

Existing Wording: Each resource has an "id" element which contains the logical identity
Proposed Wording:
..add ('literal') 

or 'logical' and be consistent.
Comments: In the next section 'Business Identifiers" it states - "The resource identity is a direct ("literal")…"
Summary: The phrase literal isn't used until the "Business Identifier" section and it's unclear whether the spec is referring to id or identifier.

Existing Wording: reosurce
Proposed Wording: resource

Existing Wording: The resource identity is a direct ("literal") reference that is intended to be accessed via http for a resource to be returned. As a resource is copied from server to server, the resource identity will change as the servers assign identities to the resource.
Comments: Did you consider adding an example on search access with the 'business identifier'? Or reference to search page for this example?
Summary: A simple example, or reference to search, on howto acces by business identifier rather than literal resource id might help the new reader.

Existing Wording: PI
Comments: Please spell PI out. Protected information?

Existing Wording: The server MAY include a response body containing an OperationOutcome resource with hints and warnings about the resource; if one is sent it SHALL not include any errors.
Comments:
Does this mean OperationOutcome .issue.severity cannot = error? Why?

Maybe we should add a sentence -- 'An error on update would return a the appropriate error in 'Rejecting Updates".

Existing Wording: Not, however, that existing transaction boundaries are not represented in a history list,
Proposed Wording: Note, however, that existing transaction boundaries are not represented in a history list,

Existing Wording: The content of the post submission is a Bundle with type set to transaction. Each entry carries a transaction
Proposed Wording: The content of the post submission is a Bundle with Bundle.type="transaction". Each Bundle entry carries a transaction

Existing Wording: N/A

The potential perumtations on 0..* will require custom programming for many exchanges.

Proposed Wording: <remove>
Comments: Please describe how systems use class/type or remove.

Existing Wording: Take "as needed" f(or x
Proposed Wording: "Take 'as needed'; Or take for specific condition (precondition)

Proposed Wording: "...except the search with parameter _id returns a bundle with the requested resource, rather than the resource itself."

Existing Wording: medication -> Reference (Medication)
Proposed Wording: N/A

Existing Wording: N/A
Proposed Wording: Did you consider listing the supported comparators or the minimum you expect systems to support?

Existing Wording: This allows for simple combinations of and/or values, but doesn't allow a search based on a pair of values, such as all observations with a sodium value >150 mmol/L (particularly as the end criteria of a chained search), or searching on Group.characteristic: you need find a combination of key/value, not an intersection of separate matches on key and value. Another example is spatial coordinates when doing geographical searches.
Proposed Wording: N/A
Comments: Please add an example.

Existing Wording: The result of the search operation is the intersection of the resources that match the criteria specified by each individual search parameter
Proposed Wording: Composite search parameters supports joining single values with a "$". For example…
Comments: The other sections use the first sentence to define the parameter -- would be great to follow pattern here.

Section: 2.1.1.4.3 Including other resources in result (_include and _revinclude)
Existing Wording: The client requests that the subject resources be included in the results set by providing one or more _include parameters. An alternative scenario is where the client wishes to fetch a particular resource, and any resources that refer to it. For example, the client may wish to fetch a MedicationPrescription, and any provenance resources that refer to the prescription. This is known as a reverse include, and specified by providing a _revinclude parameter.
Proposed Wording:
A client may use the _include parameter to indicate the subject resources be included in the results.

A client may use the _revinclude parameter to fetch a particular resource, and any resources that refer to it. For example, the client may wish to fetch a MedicationPrescription, and any provenance resources that refer to the prescription. This is known as a reverse include, and specified by providing a _revinclude parameter.
Comments: Just trying to highlight difference with parallel sentences.

mode 0..1 string

Existing Wording: values should be 1-23, X, Y, mitochondrial, viral, bacteria
Proposed Wording: Values should follow standard cytogenetic nomenclature.
Comments: If value constraints are applied at this level, then the system of chomosome specification needs to be replaced with one that works for all use cases.  For example, some organisms have more than 23 pairs of chromosomes.  As another example, simply specifying bacterial would not work by itself, because some bacteria have multiple chomosomes.

Existing Wording: (Entire page contents)
Proposed Wording: To provide this the resolution team would have to first consider the idea of developing a Profile that contained extensions to the Observation that would permit the use of Observation sets to delineate between the major types of observations performed by genetic testing labs during the multi-step testing processes that they provide.  See comments for further explanation.
Comments:
There are testing centers that run genotyping or sequencing tests to simply identify the presence or absence of a given genotype in specific patient tissue (germline, tumor , prenatal) as well as in viral or bacterial organisms found within a patient.  There are also labs that perform interpretive services on the findings produced by wet lab and bioinformatic processes.  The interpretive services are not always included but can be performed as a secondary service at the lab identifying the genotypes or by a secondary lab that specializes in one or more clinical domain areas or even by the receiving clinician/provider that ordered the test (the treating physician).  So, it seems that we would want to define LOINC panels that group logical sets of observations together for the separate types of observations, then use an approach similar to how the Example shown for DiagnosticReport "Lipid Report" using LOINC panels to profile the constraints around providing a set of Observations that comprise a logical observations that are included with every Lipid Panel.  This concept and proper use of Profiling should be understood by the authors of the Genetics group before proceeding with an approach that simply adds a dozen or more attributes (as well intentioned as they may be) to a single Observation Resource.  I strongly recommend a review of these proper uses of Profile extensions using LOINC codes and panels, as that has historically been an important aspect of Laboratory results reporting.  With the current model there is no standard way to associate LOINC observation codes to these new set of geneticsXXX attributes.  Hardcoding or mapping is unreasonable.
     I suggest the following presentation for a quick helpful picture of how LOINC panels are used to constrain a Profile http://www.slideshare.net/ewoutkramer/authoring-fhir-profiles-extended-version starting at slide 41.  In actuality, the entire presentation is useful for understanding how and what is needed to be considered when developing a Profile.  Summary: 1) Demonstrate pragmatic examples of how profiles can be developed in FHIR, particularly around the use of LOINC codes and panels to develop Observation sets. 2) Ask the authors to identify the major workflow/service patterns performed by genetic testing labs (not super detailed). I believe they will see that there is a logical and useful separation of wet lab, variant identification/calling services from the clinical analytics/interpretation services. 3) develop the sets of observed values for the components in each phase.  For example, GenotypeObservation in the first phase with a presence or absence interpretation.  And, possibly, GeneticInterpretationObservation with the targeted set of phenotypes (germline, cancer, condition, pharmacogentic, etc) and the clinical significance as asserted by an expert geneticist.  4) With a logical grouping of the observation sets, I believe it will provide the health care community the opportunity to build up representations of complex genotypes and alleles, when needed in pharmacogentic reporting, as well as structure variants, somatic interpretation, and other state specific use cases yet to be standardized.
Summary: Example workflow, values, and grouping

Proposed Wording: Should the type be "Coding" and not "code"?
Comments: It is not clear why Coding is used for the ProvenanceAgentRole, ProvenanceAgentType, ProvenanceEntityType and not the ProvenanceEntityRole.  At minimum an explanation clarifying the more restrictive data type would be helpful.  Summary: the type "code" seems inconsistent and not clear based on how the type "Coding" has been applied to other similar attributes in the same entity. I am more than willing to change to Affirmative vote if I understood the difference.
Summary: Code inconsistent

Existing Wording: The genomic class of the variant: Germline for inherited genome, somatic for cancer genome (e.g. DNA from tumor cells), and prenatal for fetal genome.
Proposed Wording: Please define the term "source" and consistently adhere to it and its meaning.
Comments: The description initially indicates "genomic class of the variant", which at first suggests variant type (such as silent, missense, nonsense, etc.).  However, it then mentions "germline for inherited genome", which suggests that the distiction is whether a variant was one that was inherited or one that developed after a reproduction process which is inconsistent with the initially suggested idea.  It then mentions "somatic", which suggests tissue source (such as somatic cell or germ cell), which is inconsistent with both of the two previously suggested ideas.  It then mentions "cancer genome", which suggests either association with specific diseases or tissue source in terms of tumor cell, etc. type, both of which are inconsistent with all of the three previously suggested ideas (note that some genomic variants in a cancer cell could have been inherited and some variants could have arisen from somatic mutations).  It then mentions "prenatal for fetal genome", which suggests either tissue source per body location, individual person source, or developmental stage, all three of which are inconsistent with all five of the previously suggested ideas.  From this, it appears likely that multiple different ideas (possibly up to eight) are being inappropriatly conflated in this data element, and in any case the intended defintion needs to be stated for clarity, please.
Summary: Define source

Comments: The meaning of the "level of occurrence of the DNA variation" needs to be defined, please.
Summary: Define level

Existing Wording: Used to denote the condition context for genetic testing
Proposed Wording: Please specify in what way such a condition is a context for testing.
Comments: The sense in which the condition provides a context for testing needs to be specified, please.  For example, one possibility is a condition being tested for.  Another possibility is a family history of the condition.  Another possibility is a diagnosed condition in the patient that may have a pertinent association with a condition being tested for.  The specific type of context needs to be specified, please.
Summary: Define condition context

Existing Wording: A sequence of of base lengths and the associated operation, used to indicate which bases align (either a match/mismatch) with the reference, are deleted from the reference, and are insertions that are not in the reference. string of observed nucleotides. Observed nucleotides matching the reference are in capital letters. Observed nucleotides not matching the reference are in lower case letters. Use '-' a dash for deleted/missing nucleotides in the observed sequence. Allowable characters are A,T,C,G, a,t,c,g and -.
Proposed Wording: The CIGAR string of the sequence in extended CIGAR format relative to the reference sequence (Li H, Handsaker B, Wysoker A, et al. The sequence alignment/map format and SAMtools. Bioinformatics. 2009;25(16):2078.).
Comments: The name "cigar" and the "base lengths" and "operation" suggest a CIGAR string of some type (whether CIGAR or extended CIGAR is not specified).  However, "A, T, C, G, a, t, c, g, and -" suggests an alignment string instead of a CIGAR string.  The specific intended format should be specified, please.
Summary: Specify CIGAR format

Comments: Provide digital certificate resource for digital signatures that supports the X.509 V3 Public Digital Certificate and an optional ability to support a signed and dated revocation list or OCSP that can be referenced by certificate number and a date/time  by a new element in the provenance resource

Update the provenance resource to support a digital signature that references the digital certificate resource and only requires the signing of the hash of the xml representation of the object (resource, profile, document) and the remaining elements of provenance resource to reduce the overhead with digital signatures applied to FHIR resources.... (e.g.  the balance of the XADES-XL is in the digital certificate resource and may be reused for multiple signed resources as long as the OCSP or singed revocation list verifying the validity of the Certificate is contemporaneous with or post-dates the date of the last signed hash.)

Comments: A formal registry of profiles and extensions is important before FHIR is finalized. I couldn't locate a discussion of a registry or commitments to completing one before FHIR is normative.
Summary:
A pilot project within DoD/VA IPO reviewed 3 profiles on Vital Signs, including C-CDA on FHIR. It became very clear that without a robust registry profile proliferation will occur. This proliferation will require each site and vendor to develop their own FHIR profiles and will recreate the HL7 V2 problem, customization for each new site.

Requirements may necessitate differences but it would be helpful to designers to highlight differences so only meaningful changes are introduced.

Section: 2.1.1.4.3 Including other resources in result (_include and _revinclude)
Existing Wording: The client requests that the subject resources be included in the results set by providing one or more _include parameters. An alternative scenario is where the client wishes to fetch a particular resource, and any resources that refer to it. For example, the client may wish to fetch a MedicationPrescription, and any provenance resources that refer to the prescription. This is known as a reverse include, and specified by providing a _revinclude parameter.
Proposed Wording:
A client may use the _include parameter to indicate the subject resources be included in the results.

A client may use the _revinclude parameter to fetch a particular resource, and any resources that refer to it. For example, the client may wish to fetch a MedicationPrescription, and any provenance resources that refer to the prescription. This is known as a reverse include, and specified by providing a _revinclude parameter.
Comments: Just trying to highlight difference with parallel sentences.

Existing Wording:
Note the following additional rules about required bindings when used with the code data type: 
•Where the value set is defined by FHIR, the list of allowed codes will be fixed in the XML schema
Comments: This rule is problematic due to the potential of the size of this list of concepts. For example, a list of lab tests, or list of drugs.  If this rule has to be included, then it should provide additional provision on when this should only be used to ensure misuse is minimized.

Concerns for Standard Genetic Profile on Observation: - why did you restrict GeneID to HGNC instead of offering alternative terminology choices such as EntrezGene? EntrezGene IDs are commonplace in clinical genomic reporting contexts - There seems to be a large list of attributes but no guidance on which of these should be assembled together for individual Observations. Have you considered using the FHIR Slicing capability to define ways in which these attributes should be assembled - Consider expanding use cases significantly, for example how would you report a fusion gene such as BCR-ABL?

Concerns for FamilyMemberHistory: -needs additional use-cases and examples explicitly provided -it is not clear how the new FamilyMemberHistory resource will be utilized to convey meaning. seems that there will now also need a new resource for the familyHistory section of which FamilyMemberHistory will be used
it is unclear how intrinsic identifiers will be utilized to make use of the genetic-pedigree profile to avoid ambiguity
patient reported medication dosing should not require a max dose or units. For more elucidation on this issue, please read my collegue Marla Albitz comment
Suggest that the Table of HL7 V2 tables forming part of the FHIR Terminology should specify the latest version rather than allow multiple versions

The Standard Profile for Genetics is a good start for this domain, but it should be emphasized that it represents one view on reporting generic genetic results. Other profiles that represent specific use cases will no doubt reuse these extensions, but in specialized formats (e.g., histoimmunogenetics), and new extensions defined for those use cases. Separate resources/extensions that specifically define sequences and variants of those sequences will need to be created, that include metadata such as coordinate systems (0- or 1-based, and open and/or closed), which differ depending on use cases. Even in this single use case, the coordinate system is not defined which turns understanding the genomicstart and genomicstop coordinates into making trying to make an educated decision (e.g., default to whatever HGVS or VCF is using, or what BED, UCSC internal formats and Genomic Alliance standards are being used).

Conformance resource - the existing description seems to be developed ad-hoc. I would highly recommend a more structured and standards-based approach, such as the adoption of the different type of conformance points, namely interworking, programatic, perceptual and interchange reference points, as defined in the ISO/ITU-T standard, RM-ODP (ITU-T X.902 | ISO/IEC 10746-2), clause 15
FHIR section 6.16.3 does not describe all UML classes and this needs to be completed
The concept of profile needs further consolidation. Currently it is unclear what business value the separate provider and consumer profiles bring
What is difference in semantics between a profile and implementation guide ? Looks like an FHIR IG is intended for publication purpose while Profile is for specification/implementation purposes

How does FHIR fit as part of a broader architecture landscape? How does fit within HL7 SAIF specification? Many organisations find it useful to separate logical from implementable specifications as an insurance policy against change. It would be highly valuable to position FHIR as part of such a framework, which would also allow better inclusion of behaviour and policy constraints. Possibly section 3.1 can point to the HL7 SAIF
